<!DOCTYPE html>
<html b:version='2' class='v2' expr:dir='data:blog.languageDirection' expr:lang='data:blog.locale' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml' xmlns:b='http://www.google.com/2005/gml/b' xmlns:data='http://www.google.com/2005/gml/data' xmlns:expr='http://www.google.com/2005/gml/expr'>

    <b:skin><![CDATA[/*
-----------------------------------------------
Blogger Template Style
Name:     Travel
Designer: Sookhee Lee
URL:      www.plyfly.net
----------------------------------------------- */

/* Variable definitions
   ====================
   <Variable name="keycolor" description="Main Color" type="color" default="#539bcd" value="#539bcd"/>

   <Group description="Page Text" selector="body">
     <Variable name="body.font" description="Font" type="font"
         default="normal normal 13px 'Trebuchet MS',Trebuchet,sans-serif" value="normal normal 13px Ubuntu"/>
     <Variable name="body.text.color" description="Text Color" type="color" default="#bbbbbb" value="#ffffff"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Backgrounds" selector=".body-fauxcolumns-outer">
     <Variable name="body.background.color" description="Outer Background" type="color" default="#539bcd" value="#539bcd"/>
     <Variable name="content.background.color" description="Main Background" type="color" default="transparent" value="#a0a56e"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Links" selector=".main-outer">
     <Variable name="link.color" description="Link Color" type="color" default="#ff9900" value="#ff9900"/>
     <Variable name="link.visited.color" description="Visited Color" type="color" default="#b87209" value="#b87209"/>
     <Variable name="link.hover.color" description="Hover Color" type="color" default="#ff9900" value="#ff9900"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Blog Title" selector=".header h1">
     <Variable name="header.font" description="Font" type="font"
         default="normal normal 60px 'Trebuchet MS',Trebuchet,sans-serif" value="normal normal 60px Ubuntu"/>
     <Variable name="header.text.color" description="Text Color" type="color" default="#ffffff"  value="#ffffff"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Blog Description" selector=".header .description">
     <Variable name="description.text.color" description="Description Color" type="color"
         default="$(body.text.color)"  value="#bbbbbb"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Tabs Text" selector=".tabs-inner .widget li a">
     <Variable name="tabs.font" description="Font" type="font"
         default="normal bold 16px 'Trebuchet MS',Trebuchet,sans-serif" value="normal bold 16px Ubuntu"/>
     <Variable name="tabs.text.color" description="Text Color" type="color" default="#ffffff" value="#ffffff"/>
     <Variable name="tabs.selected.text.color" description="Selected Color" type="color" default="#ffffff" value="#ffffff"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Tabs Background" selector=".tabs-outer .PageList">
     <Variable name="tabs.background.color" description="Background Color" type="color" default="transparent" value="transparent"/>
     <Variable name="tabs.selected.background.color" description="Selected Color" type="color" default="transparent" value="transparent"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Date Header" selector=".main-inner h2.date-header">
     <Variable name="date.font" description="Font" type="font"
         default="normal normal 14px 'Trebuchet MS',Trebuchet,sans-serif" value="normal normal 14px Ubuntu"/>
     <Variable name="date.text.color" description="Text Color" type="color" default="$(body.text.color)" value="#ffffff"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Post Title" selector="h3.post-title a">
     <Variable name="post.title.font" description="Font" type="font"
         default="normal bold 20px 'Trebuchet MS',Trebuchet,sans-serif" value="normal bold 20px Ubuntu"/>
     <Variable name="post.title.text.color" description="Text Color" type="color"
         default="#ffffff" value="#ffffff"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Post Background" selector=".column-center-inner">
     <Variable name="post.background.color" description="Background Color" type="color"
         default="transparent" value="transparent"/>
     <Variable name="post.background.url" description="Post Background URL" type="url" default="none" value="none"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Gadget Title Color" selector="h2">
     <Variable name="widget.title.font" description="Font" type="font"
        default="normal bold 14px 'Trebuchet MS',Trebuchet,sans-serif" value="normal bold 14px Ubuntu"/>
     <Variable name="widget.title.text.color" description="Title Color" type="color" default="#ffffff" value="#ffffff"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Gadget Text" selector=".footer-inner .widget, .sidebar .widget">
     <Variable name="widget.font" description="Font" type="font"
        default="$(body.font)" value="normal normal 13px Ubuntu"/>
     <Variable name="widget.text.color" description="Text Color" type="color" default="$(body.text.color)" value="#ffffff"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Gadget Links" selector=".sidebar .widget">
     <Variable name="widget.link.color" description="Link Color" type="color" default="$(body.text.color)" value="#ffffff"/>
     <Variable name="widget.link.visited.color" description="Visited Color" type="color" default="$(link.visited.color)" value="#b87209"/>
     <Variable name="widget.alternate.text.color" description="Alternate Color" type="color" default="#ffffff" value="#ffffff"/>
   </Group>

   <Group description="Sidebar Background" selector=".column-left-inner .column-right-inner">
     <Variable name="widget.outer.background.color" description="Background Color" type="color" default="transparent"  value="transparent"/>
     <Variable name="widget.border.bevel.color" description="Bevel Color" type="color" default="transparent"  value="transparent"/>
   </Group>

   <Variable name="body.background" description="Body Background" type="background"
       color="$(body.background.color)" default="$(color) none repeat-x scroll top center" value="#539bcd url(//themes.googleusercontent.com/image?id=0BwVBOzw_-hbMYTM3ZTRlZTktYzE4ZC00NWU0LWEyMzctOWFlZjVkZTkzNGY4) repeat fixed top center"/>
   <Variable name="content.background" description="Content Background" type="background"
       color="$(content.background.color)" default="$(color) none repeat scroll top center" value="transparent url(https://resources.blogblog.com/blogblog/data/1kt/travel/bg_black_70.png) repeat scroll top left"/>
   <Variable name="comments.background" description="Comments Background" type="background"
       default="#cccccc none repeat scroll top center" value="transparent url(https://resources.blogblog.com/blogblog/data/1kt/travel/bg_black_50.png) repeat scroll top center"/>

   <Variable name="content.imageBorder.top.space" description="Content Image Border Top Space" type="length" default="0" min="0" max="100px" value="0"/>
   <Variable name="content.imageBorder.top" description="Content Image Border Top" type="url" default="none" value="none"/>

   <Variable name="content.margin" description="Content Margin Top" type="length" default="20px" min="0" max="100px" value="20px"/>
   <Variable name="content.padding" description="Content Padding" type="length" default="20px" min="0" max="100px" value="20px"/>
   <Variable name="content.posts.padding" description="Posts Content Padding" type="length" default="10px" min="0" max="100px" value="10px"/>

   <Variable name="tabs.background.gradient" description="Tabs Background Gradient" type="url"
       default="url(https://resources.blogblog.com/blogblog/data/1kt/travel/bg_black_50.png)" value="url(https://resources.blogblog.com/blogblog/data/1kt/travel/bg_black_50.png)"/>
   <Variable name="tabs.selected.background.gradient" description="Tabs Selected Background Gradient" type="url"
       default="url(https://resources.blogblog.com/blogblog/data/1kt/travel/bg_black_50.png)" value="url(https://resources.blogblog.com/blogblog/data/1kt/travel/bg_black_50.png)"/>
   <Variable name="widget.outer.background.gradient" description="Sidebar Gradient" type="url"
       default="url(https://resources.blogblog.com/blogblog/data/1kt/travel/bg_black_50.png)" value="url(https://resources.blogblog.com/blogblog/data/1kt/travel/bg_black_50.png)"/>
   <Variable name="footer.background.gradient" description="Footer Background Gradient" type="url" default="none" value="none"/>
   <Variable name="mobile.background.overlay" description="Mobile Background Overlay" type="string"
       default="transparent none repeat scroll top left" value="transparent none repeat scroll top left"/>
   <Variable name="mobile.button.color" description="Mobile Button Color" type="color" default="#ffffff"  value="#ffffff"/>
   <Variable name="startSide" description="Side where text starts in blog language" type="automatic" default="left"/>
   <Variable name="endSide" description="Side where text ends in blog language" type="automatic" default="right"/>
*/

/* Content
----------------------------------------------- */
body {
  font: $(body.font);
  color: $(body.text.color);
  background: $(body.background);
}

html body .region-inner {
  min-width: 0;
  max-width: 100%;
  width: auto;
}

a:link {
  text-decoration:none;
  color: $(link.color);
}

a:visited {
  text-decoration:none;
  color: $(link.visited.color);
}

a:hover {
  text-decoration:underline;
  color: $(link.hover.color);
}

.content-outer .content-cap-top {
  height: $(content.imageBorder.top.space);
  background: transparent $(content.imageBorder.top) repeat-x scroll top center;
}

.content-outer {
  margin: 0 auto;
  padding-top: $(content.margin);
}

.content-inner {
  background: $(content.background);
  background-position: left -$(content.imageBorder.top.space);
  background-color: $(content.background.color);
  padding: $(content.padding);
}

.main-inner .date-outer {
  margin-bottom: 2em;
}

/* Header
----------------------------------------------- */
.header-inner .Header .titlewrapper,
.header-inner .Header .descriptionwrapper {
  padding-left: 10px;
  padding-right: 10px;
}

.Header h1 {
  font: $(header.font);
  color: $(header.text.color);
}

.Header h1 a {
  color: $(header.text.color);
}

.Header .description {
  color: $(description.text.color);
  font-size: 130%;
}

/* Tabs
----------------------------------------------- */
.tabs-inner {
  margin: 1em 0 0;
  padding: 0;
}

.tabs-inner .section {
  margin: 0;
}

.tabs-inner .widget ul {
  padding: 0;
  background: $(tabs.background.color) $(tabs.background.gradient) repeat scroll top center;
}

.tabs-inner .widget li {
  border: none;
}

.tabs-inner .widget li a {
  display: inline-block;
  padding: 1em 1.5em;
  color: $(tabs.text.color);
  font: $(tabs.font);
}

.tabs-inner .widget li.selected a,
.tabs-inner .widget li a:hover {
  position: relative;
  z-index: 1;
  background: $(tabs.selected.background.color) $(tabs.selected.background.gradient) repeat scroll top center;
  color: $(tabs.selected.text.color);

}
/* Headings
----------------------------------------------- */
h2 {
  font: $(widget.title.font);
  color: $(widget.title.text.color);
}

.main-inner h2.date-header {
  font: $(date.font);
  color: $(date.text.color);
}

.footer-inner .widget h2,
.sidebar .widget h2 {
  padding-bottom: .5em;
}

/* Main
----------------------------------------------- */

.main-inner {
  padding: $(content.padding) 0;
}

.main-inner .column-center-inner {
  padding: $(content.posts.padding) 0;
}

.main-inner .column-center-inner .section {
  margin: 0 $(content.posts.padding);
}

.main-inner .column-right-inner {
  margin-left: $(content.padding);
}

.main-inner .fauxcolumn-right-outer .fauxcolumn-inner {
  margin-left: $(content.padding);
  background: $(widget.outer.background.color) $(widget.outer.background.gradient) repeat scroll top left;
}

.main-inner .column-left-inner {
  margin-right: $(content.padding);
}

.main-inner .fauxcolumn-left-outer .fauxcolumn-inner {
  margin-right: $(content.padding);
  background: $(widget.outer.background.color) $(widget.outer.background.gradient) repeat scroll top left;
}

.main-inner .column-left-inner,
.main-inner .column-right-inner {
  padding: 15px 0;
}

/* Posts
----------------------------------------------- */
h3.post-title {
  margin-top: 20px;
}

h3.post-title a {
  font: $(post.title.font);
  color: $(post.title.text.color);
}

h3.post-title a:hover {
  text-decoration: underline;
}

.main-inner .column-center-outer {
  background: $(post.background.color) $(post.background.url) repeat scroll top left;
  _background-image: none;
}

.post-body {
  line-height: 1.4;
  position: relative;
}

.post-header {
  margin: 0 0 1em;

  line-height: 1.6;
}

.post-footer {
  margin: .5em 0;
  line-height: 1.6;
}

#blog-pager {
  font-size: 140%;
}

#comments {
  background: $(comments.background);
  padding: 15px;
}

#comments .comment-author {
  padding-top: 1.5em;
}

#comments h4,
#comments .comment-author a,
#comments .comment-timestamp a {
  color: $(post.title.text.color);
}

#comments .comment-author:first-child {
  padding-top: 0;
  border-top: none;
}

.avatar-image-container {
  margin: .2em 0 0;
}

/* Comments
----------------------------------------------- */
#comments a {
  color: $(post.title.text.color);
}

.comments .comments-content .icon.blog-author {
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
  background-image: url(data:image/png;base64,);
}

.comments .comments-content .loadmore a {
  border-top: 1px solid $(post.title.text.color);
  border-bottom: 1px solid $(post.title.text.color);
}

.comments .comment-thread.inline-thread {
  background: $(post.background.color);
}

.comments .continue {
  border-top: 2px solid $(post.title.text.color);
}


/* Widgets
----------------------------------------------- */
.sidebar .widget {
  border-bottom: 2px solid $(widget.border.bevel.color);
  padding-bottom: 10px;
  margin: 10px 0;
}

.sidebar .widget:first-child {
  margin-top: 0;
}

.sidebar .widget:last-child {
  border-bottom: none;
  margin-bottom: 0;
  padding-bottom: 0;
}

.footer-inner .widget,
.sidebar .widget {
  font: $(widget.font);
  color: $(widget.text.color);
}


.sidebar .widget a:link {
  color: $(widget.link.color);
  text-decoration: none;
}

.sidebar .widget a:visited {
  color: $(widget.link.visited.color);
}

.sidebar .widget a:hover {
  color: $(widget.link.color);
  text-decoration: underline;
}

.footer-inner .widget a:link {
  color: $(link.color);
  text-decoration: none;
}

.footer-inner .widget a:visited {
  color: $(link.visited.color);
}

.footer-inner .widget a:hover {
  color: $(link.color);
  text-decoration: underline;
}

.widget .zippy {
  color: $(widget.alternate.text.color);
}

.footer-inner {
  background: transparent $(footer.background.gradient) repeat scroll top center;
}

/* Mobile
----------------------------------------------- */
body.mobile  {
  background-size: 100% auto;
}

body.mobile .AdSense {
  margin: 0 -10px;
}

.mobile .body-fauxcolumn-outer {
  background: $(mobile.background.overlay);
}

.mobile .footer-inner .widget a:link {
  color: $(widget.link.color);
  text-decoration: none;
}

.mobile .footer-inner .widget a:visited {
  color: $(widget.link.visited.color);
}

.mobile-post-outer a {
  color: $(post.title.text.color);
}

.mobile-link-button {
  background-color: $(link.color);
}

.mobile-link-button a:link, .mobile-link-button a:visited {
  color: $(mobile.button.color);
}

.mobile-index-contents {
  color: $(body.text.color);
}

.mobile .tabs-inner .PageList .widget-content {
  background: $(tabs.selected.background.color) $(tabs.selected.background.gradient) repeat scroll top center;
  color: $(tabs.selected.text.color);
}

.mobile .tabs-inner .PageList .widget-content .pagelist-arrow {
  border-$startSide: 1px solid $(tabs.selected.text.color);
}
]]></b:skin>

      <b:variable default='0' name='main.column.left.width' type='length'/>

      <![CDATA[
      body {
        min-width: $(content.width);
      }

      .content-outer, .content-fauxcolumn-outer, .region-inner {
        min-width: $(content.width);
        max-width: $(content.width);
        _width: $(content.width);
      }

      .main-inner .columns {
        padding-left: $(main.column.left.width);
        padding-right: $(main.column.right.width);
      }

      .main-inner .fauxcolumn-center-outer {
        left: $(main.column.left.width);
        right: $(main.column.right.width);
        /* IE6 does not respect left and right together */
        _width: expression(this.parentNode.offsetWidth -
            parseInt("$(main.column.left.width)") -
            parseInt("$(main.column.right.width)") + 'px');
      }

      .main-inner .fauxcolumn-left-outer {
        width: $(main.column.left.width);
      }

      .main-inner .fauxcolumn-right-outer {
        width: $(main.column.right.width);
      }

      .main-inner .column-left-outer {
        width: $(main.column.left.width);
        right: 100%;
        margin-left: -$(main.column.left.width);
      }

      .main-inner .column-right-outer {
        width: $(main.column.right.width);
        margin-right: -$(main.column.right.width);
      }

      #layout {
        min-width: 0;
      }

      #layout .content-outer {
        min-width: 0;
        width: 800px;
      }

      #layout .region-inner {
        min-width: 0;
        width: auto;
      }

      body#layout div.add_widget {
        padding: 8px;
      }

      body#layout div.add_widget a {
        margin-left: 32px;
      }
      ]]>

  <b:if cond='data:useImage'>
    <b:if cond='data:imagePlacement == "BEHIND"'>
      <!--
      Show image as background to text. You can't really calculate the width
      reliably in JS because margins are not taken into account by any of
      clientWidth, offsetWidth or scrollWidth, so we don't force a minimum
      width if the user is using shrink to fit.
      This results in a margin-width's worth of pixels being cropped. If the
      user is not using shrink to fit then we expand the header.
      -->

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Conclusion and Summary
entry.content:
After 32 long entries, it is time to bring this series of blogs to a close. 

Reflecting on our safari in Botswana, I’m struck by how transformative the experience was. From the vast, untouched landscapes of Moremi and the Okavango Delta to the raw power of witnessing lions in their natural habitat, watching the intricate social structure of elephants, every moment felt like stepping into another world. The beauty of the African wilderness lies not just in its grandeur but in its details - the delicate interplay of predator and prey, the rhythms of life under the open sky, and the profound stillness that reminds you of nature’s ancient wisdom.

A safari reinforces the understanding of the circle of life like nothing else will. For me, this was an incredibly emotional trip.

For anyone considering a safari, I hope this blog series has offered practical tips, honest insights, and perhaps even a bit of inspiration. Botswana is a destination that rewards curiosity and preparation, and whether you’re drawn to its wildlife, its people, or simply the call of the wild, it’s an adventure you’ll carry with you long after the dust settles. Here’s to many more journeys - and stories - to come.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Travel Tips - What Worked for Me (and What Didn’t), Part 3
entry.content:
In the previous post, I covered everything from footwear to torches and shower considerations—practical tips I wish I’d known before heading off on safari. But there’s still a lot more to share! This time, I’ll dive into some essential gear for truly making the most of your safari experience: cameras, binoculars, and a few other tools that can elevate your wildlife spotting and photography game.

Continuing on from Travel Tips - What Worked for Me (and What Didn’t), Part 2... 

Camera: Worth the Investment

If you have a DSLR camera, bring it along—it’s a game-changer on safari. If you don’t, consider investing in one, even a pre-owned model if you’re on a budget. A DSLR camera allows you to capture details and moments that are impossible to achieve with a phone or a basic point-and-shoot.

That said, unless you’re an experienced photographer, there’s no need to splurge on high-end cameras or lenses. I brought my trusty 16-year-old Canon 450D paired with a basic 18-55mm Canon lens and a 55-250mm Canon lens (Canon EF-S 55-250mm f/4-5.6 IS STM). 

The Canon EOS 450D (also known as the Rebel XSi) is a modest 12.2-megapixel DSLR camera released in 2008. While it's an older model, it's still capable of producing high-quality images, especially when paired with decent lenses. 

I captured nearly 3,000 photos during our 15-day safari, and they turned out beautifully. You can see a curated collection of 350 photos here: Botswana 2024: Kiran's Favourites.

Sample photo from my 16-year-old DSLR

And the hole in the ground where I was hiding for this mythic shot!

Smartphone Photography: A Useful Complement

While Chaitra’s iPhone photos (about 600 in total) were handy for their geolocation data. The iPhone photos were invaluable for creating detailed maps of our journey, which you can explore here: Botswana 2024: Safari Maps.

Binoculars: Non-Negotiable

Binoculars are an absolute must for any safari, and I can’t overstate their importance. After reading advice on r/travel and doing some research, I purchased two Vortex Diamondback binoculars:

  • 8x42 Diamondback® HD: These are perfect for general wildlife spotting and offer the best all-around option for safaris.
  • 10x42 Diamondback® HD: With higher magnification, these are excellent for birdwatching but have a narrower field of view and require steady hands. I bought this one pre-owned at half the price, making it a great deal.

If you must choose between a camera and binoculars, I’d recommend the binoculars. They help you truly experience the wildlife in its natural habitat, allowing you to observe details and behaviours that a camera simply can’t capture in real time.

And I had to pick just one binocular, I would prefer the 8x42 over the 10x42. 

For us, having one DSLR camera (often in my hand) and the two binoculars with Chaitra and Niharika ensured that all three of us got the best out of every wildlife viewing experience.

Tracking lions a km away with an 8x42 (turns out they are tracking us too!)

First Aid Kit: Don’t Skip It

We were lucky not to need a first aid kit during our safari, but a well-stocked first aid kit is essential for any trip, especially one as remote as a safari. We bought a good quality first aid kit from Boots, which covered the basics and gave us peace of mind.

We learned an important lesson on our trip to the Okavango Delta - our safari operator forgot their first aid kit, and we didn’t think to double-check. Thankfully, we didn’t need it, but it’s a mistake we won’t make again. Next time, we’ll ensure both we and the operator have one on hand.

In addition to the first aid kit, we packed a small stash of medications, including PPI antacids, analgesics, and antipyretics. This turned out to be a lifesaver when we caught a virus during the safari. Our supply of paracetamol kept us going.

Luggage considerations

Duffel bags (soft luggage)

On safaris, only soft luggage is allowed, so we invested in three duffel bags:

  • 60L duffel bag from Amazon for €30.
  • 60L duffel bag from Decathlon (Forclaz) for €65.
  • 55L Patagonia Black Hole duffel bag for €170.

Guess what? The €30 Amazon bag worked just as well as the €170 Patagonia one. Unless brand matters to you, save your money and go with something affordable like the Amazon option.

Backpacks

Each of us brought a backpack (20-25L), which worked perfectly for carrying essentials like cameras, snacks, and water. We just brought what we already had at home.

Packing Cubes

Highly recommended advice from r/travel: bring packing cubes. And to think I had never used or known of packing cubes! These packing cubes kept our clothes and gear organized throughout the trip. If you don’t already have some, do yourself a favour and buy them. You won’t regret it.

Locks: Keep It Safe

We usually don’t lock our luggage, but for this trip, we decided to buy TSA-approved locks. If you’re heading on a safari or traveling through airports, it’s worth buying TSA locks.

Travel Diary: A Decision I’m Glad I Made

Bringing a travel diary was the best decision ever. Every day, after lunch, I jotted down the events and wildlife sightings from the past 24 hours. Without it, this blog wouldn’t exist. Never again going on a trip without a travel diary.

Timing Your Safari: Full Moon Magic

Lions typically hunt at night and sleep during the day, except on full moon nights. During these nights, the brighter visibility makes their night-time hunts less successful, so they often continue hunting into dawn and early morning.

We didn’t plan for this, but it just so happened that we were in Moremi and Savuti on both sides of a full moon. The result? We witnessed nine lions take down and devour a full-grown buffalo in broad daylight. 

Next time, we’ll intentionally plan our safari around the full moon.

Recommended Reading: Know Before You Go

After returning from the safari, my curiosity about lion and elephant behaviour led me to some excellent books:

  • The Elephant Whisperer: A heartfelt account of a man’s bond with wild elephants.
  • The Last Lions: A powerful exploration of the challenges facing lions today.
  • The Last Giants: The Rise and Fall of the African Elephant: A sobering account.
  • The Lion: Behaviour, Ecology, and Conservation of an Iconic Species: A deep dive into lion ecology and behaviour. The best book of the lot, with every observation backed by lots of stats, graphs and charts. For someone like me (who likes to back everything with data), this was a most absorbing read.

Reading these before your safari will give you a greater appreciation for the wildlife you’ll encounter.

Recommended Watching: Into the Okavango

Before our trip, we watched Into the Okavango, a National Geographic documentary. It provided a wonderful introduction to the Okavango Delta’s ecosystem and wildlife. For our next safari, we’ll do the same - read LP guides, watch location-appropriate documentaries, and dive into a few good books. 

Fun fact: our guide in Okavango, Orphan was on the Into the Okavango team. 

Preparation truly adds to the experience.

Final words on safari operators and the safari contract

I have already written about choosing the right safari operator. 

Once you’ve selected an operator, they’ll issue a contract before you pay. Read it carefully and identify what your personal negotiables and not negotiables are. Remember, this is a safari in the wilderness - things won’t always go as planned, and the contract likely won’t be fulfilled 100%. That’s something you need to be ok with.

Some examples from our safari:

  • A long night drive was promised in Khwai, but Kem, our guide, wasn’t comfortable driving after dark. Instead, we had a shorter night drive, which didn’t yield much. It wasn’t a big deal; the rest of the safari was outstanding.
  • Every dinner was supposed to be a three-course meal. However, on three occasions, we arrived late at camp: once due to a burst tire, once because we lingered at too many wildlife sightings, and once because the drive simply took longer than expected. Shine didn’t have time to prepare dessert on those nights. For us, that was perfectly fine.
    • I’ve read reviews where people were upset because a dessert or beer was missed. Honestly, I find that baffling. A safari is about connecting with nature, not obsessing over desserts.
  • A boat ride in Moremi was on the itinerary, but we spent the morning watching nine lions take down and feast on a buffalo. Kem stayed with us until well past noon to savour the moment - just us, with no one else in sight. With the drought limiting water levels in the delta, missing the boat ride was no loss. Watching the lions in such an intimate setting was more than worth it.
Ultimately, while the contract wasn’t followed to the letter, it was fulfilled in spirit. For me, that’s what matters. This was a five-star experience, regardless of the minor deviations. 

Notes about today

Soft Luggage on Safari

Soft luggage is essential for safaris due to practical constraints in both 4WD vehicles and light aircraft. The luggage compartments in these modes of transport are often small and oddly shaped, requiring bags that can be easily manipulated to fit into tight spaces. Most safaris enforce strict weight limits, typically ranging from 15 to 20 kg per person, including hand luggage. This restriction is particularly important for light aircraft flights, where space and weight are at a premium.

The recommended dimensions for safari luggage are usually around 30cm x 30cm x 70cm, though this can vary slightly depending on the specific safari operator. 

Lion Hunting Patterns and Lunar Cycles

Lion hunting patterns are significantly influenced by the lunar cycle, primarily due to the amount of available light. Lions are most successful in their hunts during darker nights. During full moon nights, when there's abundant moonlight, lions often struggle to hunt successfully. The bright moonlight makes them more easily detectable by their prey, reducing their chances of a successful kill.

Research has shown that lions' food intake is generally higher during moonless nights. In one study, lions were observed not hunting for over two hours after dark on a full moon night, but successfully killed within minutes of the moon setting.

The moon rises about 50 minutes later each night, creating periods of darkness after sunset in the days following a full moon, which benefits lion hunting. Lions are found to be most successful in hunts in the 2-3 days following the full moon night due to the late moon rise.

This demonstrates how closely lion hunting patterns are tied to the availability of darkness and the cover it provides. Understanding these patterns can enhance the safari experience, allowing visitors to better anticipate and potentially observe lion behaviour in relation to the lunar cycle.

entry.content:
Continuing on with the practical tips from Travel diaries: Botswana 2024: Practical Tips - What Worked for Me (and What Didn’t), Part 1... 

Here I am, nestled in my family farmhouse in the Western Ghats of India, sipping on a steaming cup of coffee on a mild winter morning. The mist is just starting to lift, revealing our arecanut farm in front of the farmhouse. It's the perfect setting to continue our chat about Botswana.

Food and drinks

Snacks

Speaking of snacks: we brought energy bars, almonds, and cashews. Our operator was so well-prepared that we need not have brought anything. To be safe, we’ll continue to bring these three on future safaris.

Since we weren’t going to bring any of this back with us, we naturally shared the bars and dry fruits with Kem, Shine, and KG. They seemed genuinely grateful, and we were only happy to share.

Sundowner

What's a safari without sundowners - right? Most operators will bring local beers and wines. We found both to be of good quality and very palatable. 

If you want something special, buy it in Gabrone, Maun or Kasane before starting on your safari. I brought a bottle of scotch (Kem drank most of it really) and G&T for the Chobe River cruise. For Chaitra and me, this was more than enough to elevate the experience.

Veg or non-veg?

I didn’t entirely trust the fridge in our safari vehicle – it was fine for keeping beers cool, but I wasn’t convinced it could keep meat safe.

So, we opted for an all-vegetarian diet, and Shine cooked up some fantastic vegetarian meals. This lad can cook! 

Shower Considerations

When we planned our safari in June (Botswana’s peak winter, with night temperatures dropping to around 5°C), we weren’t sure how we’d handle open-air showers. To prepare, we brought six packs of biodegradable WaterWipes (360 sheets in total) for daily full-body wipe-downs. These worked perfectly and kept us feeling fresh without needing to brave the cold every day. You can check them out here: WaterWipes.

That said, I did shower in the bush twice, and it was incredibly refreshing - there’s nothing like washing all that dust out of your hair. For our next safari, I’ll plan to shower more often and rely less on wipes.

One thing I forgot, though, was face wipes or tissues. Using water wipes for everything was fine, but next time I’ll bring moisturizing face tissues for an extra bit of comfort.

To see the shower setup (and tent setup in general), view the videos below. 

Tent and shower at Moremi GR

Campsite in Okavango delta

Campsite in Savuti

Linen

Our safari operator provided bed linen and towels, which were replaced midway through our 10-day trip. This might vary with other operators, so it’s worth checking ahead.

We also brought our own microfibre travel towels for showers, and they worked brilliantly. They dry quickly, are compact, and are much easier to manage than traditional towels.

Electronic Items

We brought our phones and bought BTC SIM cards in Botswana. BTC has the best coverage across the country, but be prepared for long stretches of no signal during the safari. If you’re staying in urban areas, Orange has the best data coverage.

For charging, we relied on one power bank per two people. Ideally, your power bank should be able to fully charge two phones on a single charge. We charged the power banks in the safari vehicle while driving and used them to charge our phones overnight.

Watches

I brought my trusty Seiko 5 automatic watch, while Chaitra and Niharika brought their smartwatches. Charging the smartwatches turned out to be a hassle, and next time, we’ll all stick to mechanical automatic watches.

Torches and Headlamps

For night-time visibility, we brought small but powerful LED torches - one per person, plus a spare. Headlamps, however, were the real MVPs. We brought one per person, also with a spare, and chose models with a red-light option (like this one). The red light was incredibly useful at night, as it allowed our eyes to adjust back to the dark quickly after use.

The Value of Torches with Red Lights

Red-light torches are essential for night use in the jungle, as they provide visibility without startling wildlife or disrupting the serene environment. Unlike white light, red light doesn’t constrict your pupils, allowing your eyes to adjust back to the dark quickly once the light is off. This makes them perfect for stargazing, where you can instantly transition from using the torch to admiring the starry sky. They’re also ideal for night-time navigation in camp, ensuring minimal impact on your surroundings. Compact and practical, a red-light torch is a small yet invaluable tool for any safari adventure.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Travel Tips - What Worked for Me (and What Didn’t), Part 1
entry.content:
After two unforgettable weeks exploring Botswana’s stunning landscapes, diverse wildlife, and warm hospitality, it’s time to conclude the Botswana series of blogs.

As a first-time safari-goer, I had my fair share of questions and uncertainties while planning for this adventure. In this final post, I’ll share as much information as I can from the perspective of someone navigating the safari experience for the first time—what to bring, what to leave behind, and lessons learned along the way. I hope this post offers some useful insights to help you prepare for your own adventure of a lifetime.

It’s going to be a long one, so grab a cup of coffee (or a sundowner if you’re feeling safari vibes), and if you’re actually planning, maybe a pencil and some paper too.

NOTE: Some of what I write below is specific to Botswana and Namibia - especially when it comes to what to wear. For Kenya, Tanzania, and Zimbabwe, some of these recommendations may not apply.

Research: Start Smart

If you’re planning a safari, start with some solid research. Specifically, SafariBookings.com is excellent for comparing multiple safari options. Once you’ve shortlisted a few operators, head over to TripAdvisor to dig into their reviews - it’s my go-to for real feedback. For deeper, uncensored discussions, check out r/travel. And then, of course, there’s Lonely Planet.

While Lonely Planet (LP) guides aren’t as good as they were 20 years ago, they’re still one of the least biased sources of information out there. Between Chaitra, Niharika, and me, we combed through the LP guides for Botswana, Namibia, Tanzania and Kenya, compared notes, and ultimately settled on Botswana.

Our reasons? Botswana is the most unspoiled of the four, less commercial, and offers better chances of enjoying wildlife without competing with other vehicles. Turns out, my assessment was spot on!

A Word of Advice

Here's my two cents: skip the flashy YouTube videos, glossy websites, and especially those Instagram reels by self-proclaimed "Africa influencers." Stick to TripAdvisor, Reddit, and Lonely Planet for practical, down-to-earth advice that will actually help you plan your trip.

 Self-Drive or Guided Safari?

This was a big decision. After getting quotes, I realized that self-drive would cost almost the same as a guided tour with bush camping. The difference? With self-drive, I wouldn’t have access to Mobnet (the essential safari radio network), and I’d be navigating unfamiliar terrain.

With guided tours, I had the advantage of an experienced driver, better wildlife spotting, and less stress overall. So, the decision made itself.

High-End or Budget?

In Botswana, safari options are pretty polarizing. On one end, you have luxury camps charging $1000 (and upward) per person, per night. On the other, you’ve got bush camping with pit latrines and open-to-the-sky showers.

Let’s be real: I couldn’t afford the luxury camps, so bush camping it was. It’s raw, it’s real, and it’s what a safari should be. I did not regret my choice one bit. 

Choosing the Right Safari Operator

Finding the right safari operator is crucial - it can make or break your trip. After a ton of research, we got quotes from three operators and finally went with Shipungo Safari & Tours. What clinched it for me? Mark, the guy who runs Shipungo, patiently answered every single one of my questions, no matter how silly they might have seemed. 

I told him this was the trip of a lifetime for us, and he delivered. The vehicles were top-notch, and the team he provided - our guides (Orphan, Kem, and Tops), the chef (Shine), and the camp hand (KG) - were simply superb.

The takeaway: a good operator and guide can make all the difference. Take your time to pick wisely.

What to Wear on Safari: Finding the Balance

Some websites will tell you to invest in ridiculously expensive gear, while others say, “Don’t bother buying anything—you probably already have neutral colours in your wardrobe.” From my experience, the truth lies somewhere in between.

In our full safari gear

Undergarments: Don’t Skimp

We packed one set of undergarments per day, plus a couple of spares. On my first safari, the last thing I wanted to do was spend precious time doing laundry when I could be soaking in Africa’s magic. For women, good sports bras are non-negotiable. Safari drives are bumpy—very bumpy—and without adequate support, you’ll feel sore by the end of the day.

Socks: Double Up

Sweat and dust are unavoidable on safari, making it necessary to bring two pairs of socks per day. Woollen socks, in particular, are lifesavers for those early morning game drives when the chill can cut right through you.

Footwear

If a walking safari is part of your trip, bring good walking shoes. Else, your usual sneakers will do. Your shoes must breathe! I brought my Gore-Tex shoes which don't breathe really well, causing my feet to perspire excessively. Chaitra and Niharika brought regular sneakers that breathed well, and they were better off. 

We also packed flip-flops but never used them, so I’d skip those next time. However, we did bring spare sneakers for everyone (just in case), and I’d do the same again - they’re a good backup option if something happens to your primary pair. 

Trousers: Lightweight and Durable

For safari drives, Craghoppers Nosilife trousers were fantastic. They’re lightweight, offer sun and insect protection, and kept us surprisingly warm during cold mornings. Two pairs for a 10-day safari were plenty - just rotate them.

Also, bring a pair of regular trousers for evenings in town.

Shirts: Keep It Simple

Again, Craghoppers Nosilife shirts were a hit - lightweight, protective, and perfect for layering. Two long-sleeved shirts for game drives worked well. For layering, we also brought a few neutral-coloured vests and t-shirts.

If you plan to spend time in town, pack a couple of regular shirts or tops.

Sleeping

We brought 2 sets of comfy jammies - again because we did not want laundry hassles. 

Accessories: Must-Haves

  • Tube Scarf: This was a game-changer. It protected us from the sun and acted as a dust filter for our noses during dusty drives.
  • Boonie Hat: Absolute must. It keeps the sun off your face and neck, especially on walking safaris.
  • Woollen caps and gloves (the oldest ones you have in your wardrobe - they will get very dusty)

The Key to Comfort: Layering

Mornings on safari start chilly, so dressing in layers is essential. Start with a long-sleeve t-shirt or vest, add a Nosilife shirt, a fleece jumper, and finish with a woollen hat and gloves. By mid-morning, as the sun rises, you’ll start shedding layers. By lunchtime, you’ll be down to just your t-shirt. The reverse happens during evening drives and dinners.

All wrapped up for the morning drive

And the layers start coming off by noon

Keeping warm during dawn and dusk game drives

Some safari vehicles carry parkas. Where they don't, bring the fleece from your bedding with you for warmth between 06:30 and 07:30, and then from 18:30 to 19:30. 

Woollen cap and woollen gloves are a good idea also. I often borrowed my daughters fingerless gloves to keep my hands warm while I photographed. 

Clothing Colours: Do They Matter?

Unlike some parts of Africa, Botswana is tsetse fly-free, so you don’t have to avoid blues or dark colours. Stick to neutral tones like olive, beige, or khaki for blending into the environment.

Laundry on Safari

When bush camping, water is at a premium, so doing laundry can be tricky. If you plan to wash clothes, pack a good travel detergent.

Our original plan: no laundry. But with all the dust around, we ended up doing a round of laundry on day 6 of the safari. We used body wash since we did not bring travel detergent.

What I Forgot (and Will Bring Next Time)

  • Anti-Bacterial Travel Socks: Socks with silver in them are great for sweaty, dusty days.
  • Woollen Cap: I forgot mine, but Chaitra and Niharika brought theirs. Smart move - it’s a must for cold mornings.

What We Bought

Our gear purchases were driven by discounts and availability at the time, and we found a few gems. Here’s the complete list:

  • Tube Scarf: NosiLife Tube Scarf II from Craghoppers (no longer available). 

  • Men’s T-Shirts: Craghoppers T-Shirt - practical for layering.

  • Men’s Shirts: Nosilife Adventure Long-Sleeved Shirt III in Woodland Green

  • Men’s Trousers:

    • Mountaindale™ Cargo Trousers from Columbia (no longer available).
    • Nosilife Cargo Trouser III in Pebble.

  • Men’s Fleece Jumper: Torney II Half Zip Fleece in Balsam Green Marl (no longer available).

  • Ladies’ Shirts: Nosilife Pro Long-Sleeved Shirt III in Wild Olive.

  • Ladies’ Trousers:

    • Nosilife Jules Trouser in Wild Olive.
    • Columbia Girls’ Silver Ridge Utility Cargo Hiking Trousers.
    • Chaitra also bought a couple of shirts and trousers from Dunnes (this is Ireland specific). They worked just fine - only they were heavy and bulky.

  • Ladies’ Fleece Jumper: Miska VI Half Zip Fleece in Meadow Haze (no longer available).

  • Hats: Columbia Bora Bora II Boonie Hat.

The rest of our gear came from our existing wardrobe - neutral-toned basics like t-shirts, vests, and trousers worked perfectly.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 14 - 15, Kasane - Gabs - JNB - AUH - DUB (26 - 27 June)
entry.content:
The Journey Home Begins

After two weeks of unforgettable wildlife encounters, tranquil river cruises, and experiences that left us in awe of Botswana’s beauty, it was time to head home. Yesterday’s serene Chobe River cruise felt like the perfect farewell, but this morning marked the beginning of our long journey back to Dublin. Starting the day with leftover pizza from Pepe Nero’s dinner the night before, we packed up, ready to bid Botswana goodbye. 

Irene, ever gracious, dropped us at Kasane Airport at 9:30 AM, setting us off on the first leg of our journey. For those planning a trip, her Airbnb listing can be found here.

Kasane to Gaborone via Francistown

Our route home included three legs on Air Botswana flights: Kasane to Francistown, Francistown to Gaborone (Gabs, as the locals call it), and finally, Gaborone to Johannesburg.

Kasane - Francistown - Gabs - JNB

Unfortunately, a cloudy day dashed my hopes of admiring Botswana’s terrain from the air, so I focused on the silver lining: Air Botswana’s excellent snacks. On each leg, we were treated to biltong (which we declined; we don’t eat beef), peanuts, dried mango strips, baobab fruit drink (a mix of baobab fruit powder in milk with natural flavouring), soda, and a selection of surprisingly good white and red wines. By the time we landed, I’d more than compensated for the lack of views with snacks and wine.

Upon arrival in Gaborone, we collected our luggage and moved from the domestic terminal to the international terminal. This explained why through check-in wasn’t an option. Gaborone Airport, however, impressed us with its efficiency and ease, making the transition smooth.

Elephant of tusks, Gabs airport

The officer asked to see Niharika’s birth certificate, which we didn’t have on hand. She was displeased, both with us and the officer in Maun who hadn’t asked for it when we entered Botswana. A lesson learned: when traveling to Africa with a minor, always carry their birth certificate.

The international terminal was interesting. The bustling atmosphere and abundance of Hindi and Gujarati speakers were a reminder of the strong Indian diaspora and expat presence in Africa. Our flight from Gaborone to Johannesburg was uneventful, with more lovely snacks and wine to keep us company.

Overnight at Johannesburg

At Johannesburg’s O.R. Tambo Airport, everything went smoothly. Shuttle services to nearby hotels departed from behind the Intercontinental Hotel, and we arrived at the Holiday Inn near the airport for our overnight stay. The hotel delivered exactly what we needed: comfortable rooms, efficient service, and reliable shuttles. It was a welcome pause before our long-haul flights to Abu Dhabi and Dublin.

Chaos at Passport Control, Again

The following morning, we returned to O.R. Tambo Airport, bracing for what we suspected would be another chaotic experience at passport control - and we weren’t wrong. Only three of ten booths were manned, officers squabbled, and passengers cut the queue as they raced to catch their flights. What we’d encountered on June 12 wasn’t an anomaly; it’s simply how O.R. Tambo operates.

I noticed something interesting with the escalators. Unlike Dublin Airport, where a lift hunt is mandatory if you have a large luggage trolley, O.R. Tambo’s escalators are designed to accommodate them. A small yet practical detail that might come in handy for someone new to the airport.

Once through the bottleneck, we indulged in a little window shopping and ended up at an “Out of Africa” store. Chaitra and Niharika picked out necklaces and a bracelet, while I found a stylish impala skin Pudney hat.

Impala skin hat - now my prized possession

Final Leg to Dublin

Our Etihad flights from Johannesburg to Abu Dhabi and then Abu Dhabi to Dublin were uneventful - a peaceful end to our journey. By the time we landed in Dublin on June 27, it felt surreal to be back home. While the wilds of Botswana seemed a world away, the memories of elephants, leopards, river sunsets, and the kindness of the people we met will stay with us forever.

Kasane - Francistown - Gabs - JNB - AUH - DUB

Notes about today

Child Travel Requirements in Africa

Since 2016, several African countries, including South Africa and Botswana, have implemented regulations requiring additional documentation for minors (children under 18) traveling across borders. These measures aim to combat human trafficking and enhance child protection. In addition to a valid passport, minors often need an unabridged birth certificate showing both parents' details. If only one parent or a guardian is traveling, additional documents like parental consent affidavits or court orders may be required.

These regulations are strictly enforced by immigration authorities, and failure to provide the necessary documents can result in delays or denied entry. Requirements may vary slightly between countries and can change over time.

While the UK foreign affairs website mentions all this, the Ireland travel website's Botswana page does not mention the need to bring full form birth certificates for minors travelling to Botswana. 

Leather industry in Botswana and Ethical Considerations

While Botswana’s leather industry is growing, sourcing high-quality leather products like my impala skin hat often requires a trip to neighbouring South Africa. This is partly because Botswana is still developing its retail outlets for leather goods, despite having a robust wildlife management and conservation program that supports ethical sourcing. Products like impala or buffalo leather items are typically derived from animals harvested under sustainable quotas or conservation efforts, ensuring that ecological balance is maintained. By utilizing these byproducts, the leather trade contributes to local economies and minimizes waste, turning a practical necessity into a valued craft.

Crocodile farming, particularly near Kasane, offers another perspective on Botswana’s potential for the leather industry. Farms like the Chobe Crocodile Farm not only produce high-quality exotic leathers but also promote wildlife conservation by reducing reliance on wild harvesting. Ethical considerations, however, remain essential. Supporting farms and outlets that adhere to animal welfare standards and transparent sourcing practices is crucial for ensuring sustainability. For travellers, choosing leather items with a verified ethical background can turn a purchase into a meaningful connection with Botswana’s conservation story.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 13, Afternoon Chobe River Cruise - Again! (25 June)
entry.content:
A Quiet Start to the Day

After 13 consecutive days of early starts, we allowed ourselves a late morning today. A leisurely breakfast, thanks to Chaitra’s efforts in the kitchen, set a relaxed tone for the day. By mid-morning, we left the Airbnb and took a taxi to President Avenue, getting dropped off near Spar. While Chaitra and Niharika explored the roadside stalls for souvenirs, I discovered that the stall owners also offered prepaid mobile top-ups. It was a convenient, no-fuss arrangement that reminded me of similar setups back home in India.

Lunch and an Afternoon on the River

This day was left unplanned as a buffer in case of delays during our safari, so we had the luxury to decide on the spot. For lunch, we tried Pepe Nero, an Italian restaurant Irene had recommended. The rooftop setting and good food made for a pleasant meal before we decided to book another Chobe River cruise with African Caribbean Safaris. Tops arranged the boat, and we paid 2,100 BWP in cash before meeting Stephen, our captain and guide for the afternoon.

With today's guide: Stephen

Stephen proved to be yet another excellent guide, continuing our streak of outstanding experiences with Botswana’s guides. Their professionalism, knowledge, and ability to make the wilderness come alive for visitors never fail to impress. 

The cruise followed the same route as yesterdays, but with overcast skies and a slower pace. See the map below for routes travelled today. 

Map: Kasane and Chobe River Cruise - take 2

Wildlife sightings didn’t disappoint. A group of five bull elephants stole the show, especially the interactions between the group leader and the younger ones. See photos below.

Four bull elephants walk up to our boat (the 5th joins later)

The patriarch shakes his head at us (he is a bit of a show-off)

Dinner time! (grey heron)

He keeps a wary eye on us (and the baboons look on)

Later, we enjoyed a quiet moment watching the sunset over the river, accompanied by a surprise G&T I had packed for Chaitra. 

Sundowner. our last one for this trip

Winding Down in Kasane

Back on land, we returned to Pepe Nero for dinner, where the terrace setting was even more enjoyable in the cool evening breeze. Safari footage played quietly on a large outdoor screen, adding a fitting touch to our final night in Botswana. The cocktails were excellent, but the mocktails - Niharika’s choice - were even better, showcasing the same attention to detail that had impressed us during lunch.

On the way back, we stopped at a roadside shop and picked up a teak hippo figurine - a foot long, 8 inches tall, and impressively heavy. It reached Dublin unscathed and now sits proudly as a mantelpiece, a tangible reminder of our time in Botswana.

Back at the Airbnb, we packed for tomorrow’s flight home, wrapping up our last evening in this extraordinary country.

Notes About Today’s Sightings

Older Bull Elephants and Bachelor Herds

Observing the interactions within the group of bull elephants during our Chobe River cruise underscored the vital role of older bulls in elephant societies. These senior bulls, often patriarchs within bachelor herds, serve as mentors, guiding younger males through the complexities of adult life. Their experience helps the younger bulls navigate key challenges, from identifying hidden waterholes and safe foraging areas to tempering aggression and dealing with stress, particularly during musth - a period of heightened hormones and potential volatility.

The 5th bull arrives; waits for the don to acknowledge its arrival

In their absence, younger bulls can become unruly or overly aggressive, leading to disruptions in elephant behaviour and even conflicts with humans. Research has shown that older bulls help stabilize these groups, teaching essential survival skills and maintaining social harmony. Without their presence, young bulls may lack critical guidance, resulting in erratic behaviour that can impact both elephant populations and local communities​​.

This dynamic highlights why the trophy hunting of older bull elephants can have far-reaching consequences. While it might seem harmless to target individuals who are no longer breeding, removing these experienced leaders creates knowledge gaps that ripple through entire herds. Older bulls are repositories of wisdom, passing down essential knowledge through direct mentorship. Preserving these mature individuals isn’t just about conserving individual animals; it’s crucial for ensuring the stability and continuity of elephant societies​​.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 12, Chobe River Cruise (24 June, Day 10 of safari)
entry.content:
An Evening on the Chobe River

After a quick stop at Irene's Airbnb to drop off our bags, we made our way back to the boat launch point. There, we were met with the sight of a small private boat from African Caribbean Safari waiting for us, the perfect vessel for an intimate Chobe River cruise. Before setting off, we had one final moment with Kem, Shine, and KG, our incredible safari team, who introduced us to Tops, our captain and guide for the evening. With heartfelt goodbyes, we waved to Kem and his team for the last time and stepped aboard.

with Tops - our Chobe River cruise guide

Setting off just after 3 PM, the cruise took us along a 15-kilometer route around a small island in the Chobe River. Tops, yet another exemplary guide, shared his knowledge with understated confidence and a keen eye for spotting wildlife. The Chobe Riverfront revealed its reputation as a wildlife haven, offering an abundance of sightings. Elephants waded into the shallows, washing grass to remove mud before eating - a behaviour that Tops explained helps protect their molars from wear. Crocodiles lounged along the banks; their prehistoric forms frozen in the sun. Buffalo, hippos, and even water monitor lizards made appearances, while the river's diverse birdlife added colour and song to the scene.

Yellow beaked ox peckers ride on a buffalo

Elephant washes grass before eating; egrets, grey heron, Egyptian geese for company

Fish eagle: once he lands all birds scatter

He is giving us sideways glances - and we are out of here

Map: Kasane and Chobe River Cruise

Choosing the Right River Cruise

The Chobe River offers countless options for cruises, ranging from luxury boats serving cocktails to shared group experiences. Our choice - a small private boat - proved ideal for wildlife enthusiasts. With just us and Tops, the focus remained on the animals and the rhythm of the river, uninterrupted by the chatter of large groups. If wildlife viewing is your goal, this setup is hard to beat.

Back to Town

As the sun set and cast its golden light over the river, Tops brought us back to the launch point. From there, we walked to the nearby Spar supermarket to stock up on essentials for the following day. Shopping done, we treated ourselves to dinner at Nando's, a local favourite in Kasane. The spicy chicken hit the spot after ten days of camp cooking. 

Irene had advised us earlier that while Kasane is very safe, it’s best to avoid walking from the Airbnb to town, as wildlife like elephants and buffalo occasionally wander into the area. Heeding her advice, we happily relied on taxis. The taxi ride from Spar to Nando’s, covering about 4 km, cost us 35 BWP, and after a hearty meal of spicy chicken, we took another taxi back to the Airbnb for 40 BWP (3 km).

Once back at the Airbnb, the comfort of a proper bed awaited us—a luxury we hadn’t experienced in over a week. Yet, as we drifted off to sleep, we couldn’t help but miss the familiar sounds of the African bush.

Notes About Today’s Sightings

Elephants Washing Grass:

One of the most fascinating behaviours we observed was elephants wading into the Chobe River to wash grass before eating. Tops explained that this habit serves two crucial purposes. First, it removes mud and grit from the grass, which can otherwise accelerate the wear and tear on their molars. Given that elephants replace their teeth only six times in their lifetime, preserving their molars is essential for their survival as they rely heavily on tough vegetation for sustenance. Second, the washing process helps reduce soil ingestion, which can be harmful in large amounts over time. 

Elephant washing grass before eating

Botswana’s Guide Excellence:

Botswana is renowned for its outstanding safari guides, and Tops was no exception. The country's guide certification program ensures that guides are not only knowledgeable about wildlife but also skilled in safety, communication, and delivering exceptional visitor experiences. Programs like the Botswana Wildlife Training Institute provide intensive training in animal behaviour, ecology, and conservation ethics, producing guides who are among the best in Africa. The result is guides who enrich the safari experience, turning it into an educational journey that deepens one’s appreciation for the natural world​​.

Marabou Stork - Nature’s Cleanup Crew:

Often labelled as one of the “Ugly 5” alongside the warthog, wildebeest, hyena, and Lappet-faced vulture, the marabou stork might not win awards for its looks, but its role in the ecosystem is indispensable. Known as the “undertaker bird” due to its hunched posture and dark plumage, this scavenger is a vital part of nature’s cleanup team. With its large, powerful bill, the marabou stork is well-equipped to tear into carcasses, consuming remains that might otherwise spread disease.

Marabou stork

Scavenging isn’t its only skill. Marabou storks are opportunistic feeders, hunting fish, insects, and small mammals when the opportunity arises. Their adaptability allows them to thrive in wetlands, savannas, and even urban environments, where they continue their critical work of waste management. By swiftly removing decaying matter, they help keep ecosystems healthy, reducing competition for resources among other scavengers and preventing the buildup of harmful bacteria.

African Darter: The Snake Bird of the Chobe:

The African darter, often nicknamed the “snake bird” due to its long, slender neck that resembles a snake when it swims, is another fascinating sight along the Chobe River. This aquatic bird is a master fisherman, diving beneath the surface to spear fish with its sharp, pointed beak. Its unique swimming style, with only its head and neck visible above water, adds an air of mystery to its movements.

African darter, or the snake bird

Unlike many waterbirds, the darter’s feathers aren’t waterproof, which allows it to dive and manoeuvre underwater with precision. After fishing, you’ll often spot them perched on branches or rocks, spreading their wings to dry in the sun—a signature pose that adds a dramatic touch to their silhouette.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 12, Savuti to Kasane (24 June, Day 10 of safari)
entry.content:
The Last Morning Drive

The day began as it always does on safari: with an early wake-up call and a quick breakfast before setting out on a morning drive. The two-hour drive was uneventful by Savuti’s high standards, with the usual sightings of antelope, giraffes, elephants, and the ever-present starlings and red-billed hornbills. We drove to the Savuti marsh first and then to Pump Pan. All very quiet this morning.

First sighting of the morning: bataleur

Though nothing particularly extraordinary graced our last morning in Savuti, it felt fitting to spend it immersed in the same quiet rhythm of the bush that we had come to love.

Farewell, Savuti

By the time we returned to camp, Shine and KG had packed up everything, ready for our departure. We gathered for a few group selfies with Kem, Shine, and KG. This incredible team made our first safari experience special. Saying goodbye to Savuti wasn’t easy, but it was time to move on.

(l-r) Kiran, Shine (chef), Niharika, Kem (guide), KG (camp hand), Chaitra

Drive to Kasane

The drive to Kasane was long and bumpy, covering 160 kilometers in about five hours. Along the way, we stopped at Ghoha Gate in Chobe National Park for a quick coffee break. We sipped our coffee and nibbled on rusks, and watched a small herd of elephants walk past us. 

The map below shows the driving route. 

The Changing Chobe River

Continuing on, the road from Kavimba to Kasane runs parallel to the Chobe River. The Chobe River forms the natural boundary between Botswana and Namibia. The juxtaposition of the Chobe River on one side and the Kasane Forest Reserve on the other made for a scenic drive, with elephants foraging and giraffes browsing close to the road. 

Just after passing Muchenje, we paused for lunch along the banks of the Chobe River. Kem had envisioned a quiet lunch by the water, watching hippos, birdlife, and the occasional elephants. Unfortunately, the drought had left the riverbed dry. Kem says he has never seen the Chobe riverbed before - and he is a guide for the last 10 years. Without water, there were no hippos, no birds, no nothing - just a dry riverbed with the occasional antelope grazing.

Arrival in Kasane

After lunch - the last lunch Shine is cooking for us on this trip - we continued to Kasane and arrived at the boat launch point near President Avenue. There, we were greeted by Irene, our warm and welcoming Airbnb host. After tipping our team generously and bidding emotional goodbyes to Kem, Shine, and KG, we closed the chapter on our bush camping safari. 

Kem and Orphan had been extraordinary guides throughout, and I know we’ll stay in touch with them, hoping to cross paths again when we return to Botswana.

Next up

An evening boat ride on the Chobe River.

Understanding Botswana's Ongoing Drought

Botswana has been grappling with severe drought conditions since October 2023, significantly impacting both the environment and the economy. The drought, primarily driven by El Niño-induced low rainfall and exacerbated by climate change, has led to substantial deficits in soil moisture and stressed vegetation across the region. 

The consequences of this prolonged dry spell are far-reaching. Economically, the drought has resulted in a 38% reduction in Botswana's GDP, equating to an annual loss of approximately $5.8 billion. This downturn is largely due to decreased agricultural productivity and challenges in water availability. 

Ecologically, the drought has placed immense pressure on wildlife. Species such as elephants, lions, and buffaloes are compelled to travel greater distances in search of diminishing water and food sources, leading to increased mortality rates among young animals due to starvation and exhaustion. 

In response to these challenges, the Government of Botswana declared the 2022/2023 period a severe agricultural drought year and has implemented relief measures to support affected communities. 

Looking ahead, there is cautious optimism. Meteorological experts from the Southern African Development Community (SADC) predict normal to above-normal rainfall for the region, including Botswana, from October 2024 to March 2025. This forecast suggests that the current drought conditions may ease in the coming months, potentially alleviating some of the hardships faced by both the population and the natural environment. 

While these projections offer hope, the situation underscores the importance of sustainable water management and climate adaptation strategies to mitigate the impacts of such climatic events in the future.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 11, Savuti evening drive (23 June, Day 9 of safari)
entry.content:
After a relaxed afternoon back at camp, with a satisfying lunch, a quiet siesta, and a much-needed cup of coffee, it was time to head out for our final evening drive in Savuti. With the soft afternoon light promising another magical Savuti sunset, we climbed into the safari vehicle, ready to see what this incredible place might reveal before the day ended.

This is our last evening in Savuti. Following the marsh pride across the Savuti marsh on the morning of 22 June - watching them play with the young ones and teach them the art of stalking and hunting - has been the highlight of our time here.

It’s one of those moments: I’m glad we came, a little wistful that this is our last evening in Savuti (for now), wishing we had a month to soak in this place, and quietly hoping that, Gods willing, I’ll be back someday.

A Leopard Interrupted

Barely ten minutes into the drive, the Mobnet crackled to life with news of a leopard sighting "close by." What followed was a brisk, bumpy 6-kilometer drive to the location, where we found a stunning leopardess reclining gracefully on the branches of a dead tree. We were fortunate to be the second vehicle to arrive, and for the first few moments, it was a perfect scene - just us, the leopard, and the quiet of the Savuti bush.

The leopardess rests

Then the chaos began. Within ten minutes, eight or nine safari vehicles arrived in a flurry of dust and noise. Passengers shouted across vehicles, stood up, and leaned out precariously for photos - even selfies - with the leopard. This behaviour is not just inconsiderate; it’s downright unacceptable. Safaris are meant to respect the animals and their space, not to turn them into props for personal entertainment. The leopardess, clearly stressed, got up and melted into the bush, but not before the convoy gave chase, adding to her distress. This isn’t wildlife viewing - it’s harassment. Disheartened, I asked Kem if we could leave. This kind of scene is everything a safari shouldn’t be, and I was left wondering if Botswana might follow the path of Kenya and Tanzania, where sightings are often mobbed by vehicles. If this is the price of a popular safari destination, it’s one we should reconsider paying.

From Familiar to Extraordinary

We left the crowded leopard sighting behind and made our way towards Pump Pan, taking our time and enjoying the usual sightings along the way - antelopes grazing, giraffes ambling, and elephants drifting towards the waterhole. It’s incredible how, in just over ten days, our perspective had shifted. What was once awe-inspiring now drew a casual “Oh, just another herd of kudu,” from us - a far cry from our first days, when we didn’t even know what a kudu looked like or that a tsessebe existed. It’s a reminder of how quickly familiarity sets in, even in a place as extraordinary as Botswana.

A forkl of kudu with some red billed ox peckers for the ride

At Pump Pan, we found a momentary stillness, with no immediate activity. But then, as often happens in the bush, the Mobnet came alive again: a pair of leopards, close by. When we found them, they were in the thick of the bush, mating. We listened briefly, then left them undisturbed. Back at Pump Pan, the sun began its descent, casting yet another breathtaking sunset over the water. It was the perfect close to our last evening drive in Savuti, the kind of quiet beauty that lingers long after the day is done.

Elephants at pump pan

Last sunset at Savuti (for now!)

Goodbye Savuti 

As the sun dipped below the horizon, we bid a fond farewell to the elephants at Pump Pan and made our way back to camp. Shine, ever the gracious host, prepared another delightful dinner that we savoured under the expansive African sky. Over the last of our Scotch, Kem surprised us with a spontaneous quiz. To my chagrin, I blanked on the fact that the peregrine falcon is the fastest bird in the world, capable of reaching speeds up to 242 miles per hour during its hunting dive.  However, I redeemed myself by recalling that Botswana gained its independence on 30 September 1966, a pivotal moment in the nation's history. This fortunate recollection clinched the quiz victory for me. Bragging right are mine for the evening! 

As we retired to our tents, the familiar symphony of the African night enveloped us one last time, a fitting lullaby for our final evening in this wild paradise.

Feathered Fixtures of the Bush

Throughout our safari adventure, two avian species have been omnipresent wherever we went: the starling and the red-billed hornbill. The starlings, with their iridescent plumage and melodic calls, have proven hard to photograph. They are often seen in large flocks called murmuration. These social birds play a crucial role in the ecosystem, consuming insects and seeds, and are known for their ability to mimic other bird calls and even mechanical sounds.

Starling

In stark contrast, the red-billed hornbills are rather easy to approach. These charismatic birds, immortalized by Zazu in "The Lion King," are seen gliding from bush to bush. With their distinctive long, curved red bills and black and white plumage, they look like the closest living relatives of dinosaurs. I have often seen them brazenly approaching our cooking area, looking to pilfer from cooking pots. Red-billed hornbills are vital members of the savanna ecosystem, often seen foraging on the ground for insects and small animals and even collaborating with mongooses in a mutually beneficial hunting arrangement.

Red-billed hornbill (and I thought dinosaurs were extinct!)

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 11, Savuti morning drive (23 June, Day 9 of safari)
entry.content:
We woke up to yet another chilly fresh morning. Up at 5:30, ready by 6:45 and off on the morning drive by 07:00 - the usual. Today is our last full day in Savuti. Let's see what new experiences the day has in store for us.

On the Trail of the Marsh Pride

A few minutes into our morning drive, we picked up the tracks of two male lions from the marsh pride. The fresh paw prints overlaid the tyre tracks from the previous night, a clear sign that they had passed by our camp after we'd tucked in for the night.

Paw prints overlapping our tyre tracks - they walked past out campsite overnight

Kem, our ever-knowledgeable guide, shared an interesting tidbit: predators often prefer walking along vehicle tracks. It's not just a random choice - the soft sand of these paths allows for quick and silent movement, perfect for stealthy hunters. Despite two hours of diligent tracking, the lions remained elusive, their presence known only by the telltale prints they left behind.

The 2 lions walked along this track for at least 3 kms before turning into the bush

A Fleeting Glimpse of the Lone Lioness

We gave up after 2 hours and made our way back to the Savuti marsh. The savannah didn't disappoint, offering us sightings of graceful giraffes, majestic elephants, and various antelopes dotting the landscape.

As we traversed the marsh, we noticed a caravan of 6-7 self-drive vehicles approaching from a distance, slowly and deliberately. As they drew nearer, we realized the object of their attention was a lone lioness.

New mother out on a hunt

Before I could train my camera on her, she vanished into the tall grass, leaving us with only a fleeting glimpse. Her enlarged teats suggested that she had a young litter, likely less than six weeks old, hidden away in the grass. This solitary huntress was probably on a mission to find food for her cubs. Or maybe she was off to socialize with the rest of the marsh pride. 

Marabou Pan

Next stop: yet another man-made waterhole - Marabou Pan - for our elevenses. You will several elephant bones scattered around the area - a bit of an elephant graveyard. What caught my eye was an elephant skull, still bearing its tusk.

Kem, Niharika, Chaitra and an elephant skull (with tusk!). Marabou Pan

It's a powerful testament to the country's commitment to conservation that such a valuable item can lie undisturbed by a waterhole frequented by dozens of visitors daily.

As we sipped our coffee, we were treated to a parade of wildlife coming to the pan - elephants quenching their thirst, warthogs trotting by, and jackals prowling at the edges.

A lone bull jogs in for a drink

Pumba wants a drink too

The Journey Back to Camp

Our return journey to the camp was punctuated by more wildlife encounters. We spotted a few tsessebe here, some zebras there, and even chanced upon a pair of ground hornbills enjoying a lizard for lunch. Each sighting, no matter how small, added to the tapestry of our Botswana adventure.

Tsessebe. Very shy - hard to get closer than this

Wildebeest: mother and daughter grazing

A pair of ground hornbill. Lizard for lunch today. 

The ground hornbill up close were an interesting sight. They are the largest hornbill species, live in groups of upto 10, and only the dominant pair breeds. 

Back to camp and lunch

As we approached the camp, the anticipation of another of Shine's special lunches and the promise of our final evening drive in Savuti (for this trip) filled us with a bittersweet excitement. 

Shine with freshly made bread. Lunch is ready

The morning's drive may not have yielded the lion sighting we'd hoped for, but it had offered its own unique treasures - a reminder that in the bush, every drive is an adventure, and every moment holds the potential for wonder.

Map and driving routes

The map below shows the areas we covered tracking lions and looking for game in general.

Notes About Today's Sightings

Predators and Vehicle Tracks

Large predators like lions often prefer walking on vehicle tracks for several reasons. The compacted sand provides a firmer surface, allowing for quieter and more energy-efficient movement. Additionally, these tracks often follow game trails or lead to water sources, increasing the chances of encountering prey. Research has shown that lions may use these tracks as travel corridors, especially in areas with dense vegetation.

Lioness Cub Care

Lionesses typically keep their cubs hidden for the first 6-8 weeks of life. This period is crucial for the cubs' survival, as they are extremely vulnerable to predators, including other lions. The mother will leave her cubs in a safe, secluded spot while she hunts, returning to nurse them. This isolation also allows the cubs to develop basic survival skills before being introduced to the pride. Studies have shown that this period of seclusion significantly increases cub survival rates.

Ivory Trade Ban Impact

Botswana's strict enforcement of the ivory trade ban has had a significant positive impact on elephant conservation. By eliminating the legal market for ivory, the ban has reduced poaching pressure on elephant populations. A study published in Nature Ecology & Evolution found that countries with strong governance and effective law enforcement, like Botswana, have seen more positive outcomes from the ivory ban. However, challenges remain, as illegal ivory trade persists globally.

Elephant Skull Structure

The honeycomb structure in elephant skulls is a marvel of natural engineering. This design allows for a large skull size to support the trunk and tusks while keeping the overall weight manageable. The air-filled cavities also play a role in thermoregulation and may enhance the elephant's ability to produce and hear low-frequency sounds. Research published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences has shown that this unique structure also provides shock absorption, protecting the brain during fights or falls.

Ground Hornbill Social Structure and Breeding

Southern ground hornbills live in cooperative breeding groups, typically consisting of 2 to 11 individuals. These groups are led by a dominant breeding pair, with the rest of the group members, usually males, acting as helpers. Only the dominant pair reproduces, a strategy shared with other social species like African wild dogs and wolves. This cooperative breeding system is crucial for the species' survival, as helpers assist in territory defense, feeding, and rearing chicks. Research suggests that this strategy is vital for successful reproduction, as unaided pairs struggle to rear young. The long period of parental dependence, lasting 1-2 years, means ground hornbills can typically breed successfully only every third year. This slow breeding rate, combined with their complex social structure, contributes to the species' vulnerability but also ensures that offspring receive extensive care and training, increasing their chances of survival in challenging environments.
