entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 10, Savuti sunset at pump pan (22 June, Day 8 of safari)
entry.content:
As the afternoon sun began its descent, we abandoned our search for the elusive leopard and set our sights on the next highlight of our Savuti adventure: sunset at Pump Pan.

A Pit Stop and a Picturesque Evening

On our way to the water hole, we made a quick stop at the Savuti Department of Wildlife National Park offices - to fill up our water cans for the camp. It's these little behind-the-scenes moments that remind you of the practicalities of safari life, even in the midst of such wild beauty.

Arriving at Pump Pan, we were treated to a spectacle that words can scarcely do justice. The water hole was a hive of activity as the golden hour approached. Buffalo lumbered to the water's edge, their massive forms silhouetted against the setting sun. 

They had their drink, they are off now leaving the waterhole to the elephants

Elephants, those gentle giants of the African bush, came in family groups, trunks swinging in anticipation of a refreshing drink.

His majesty arrives for a drink - alone

The occasional jackal darted in and out of view, while warthogs trotted about on their comically short legs.

This jackal pair is always at the watering hole!

As the sun dipped lower, painting the sky in a palette of oranges, pinks, and purples, the scene before us transformed into something truly magical. The reflection of the colorful sky on the still water of Pump Pan created a mirror image of beauty. It was one of those moments where you find yourself holding your breath, not wanting to disturb the perfection of nature's canvas.

The elephant herd drinks and a stork watches over them

Back to Camp and Good Night!

Returning to camp, we were greeted by another delightful dinner prepared by Shine. While his culinary skills are commendable, we found ourselves yearning for the comfort of home-cooked Indian meals. A simple plate of rice and daal would have been a cherished treat at that moment.

Dinner time (clockwise from top-left: Kem, Kiran, Niharika, Chaitra)

Retiring early, we drifted to sleep accompanied by the distant calls of hyenas, ostriches, and the grunts of lions. The full moon bathed the camp in its silvery glow, casting an ethereal light over the wilderness and enhancing the chorus of nocturnal sounds.

Full moon rising

Notably, two males from the Marsh Pride were reportedly heading toward the marsh, and we planned to track them in the morning.

Midnight Visitors: An Unexpected Elephant Encounter

I woke unexpectedly - a rare occurrence for someone who usually sleeps like a log. Time: 2 am. I cautiously made my way to our attached toilet area, a simple pit latrine cordoned off by tent cloth and open to the star-studded sky above.

As I stepped out, the source of my sudden wakefulness became clear. Loud rustling sounds were coming from alarmingly close by. I carefully peeked over the side of the enclosure. There, in the silvery moonlight, were two massive bull elephants, peacefully grazing just meters away from our tent.

Not wanting to disturb these magnificent creatures (or risk becoming the subject of their curiosity), I quickly and quietly retreated to the safety of our tent. From the tent window, I watched in awe as they went about their nocturnal foraging. At some point, lulled by their peaceful presence and the gentle sounds of their feeding, I drifted back to sleep, my dreams filled with elephants moving through a moonlit landscape.

Tomorrow...

As I closed my eyes, I couldn't help but smile at the thought of what tomorrow might bring. Another glorious day in Savuti awaited us, full of promise and the potential for more incredible wildlife encounters. In the heart of the African wilderness, every day is an adventure, and I couldn't wait to see what nature had in store for us next.

Map and driving routes

Notes About Today's Sightings

Solar Power in Africa: Powering Conservation

The use of solar power in African wildlife conservation, such as for powering water pumps at man-made water holes in Savuti, is a prime example of how renewable energy is making a positive impact across the continent.

  • Solar power is particularly well-suited to many African regions due to high levels of solar radiation. In wildlife areas, solar-powered systems offer several advantages:
  • Reliability: Solar panels provide a consistent power source in remote areas where grid electricity is unavailable.
  • Low Maintenance: Once installed, solar systems require minimal upkeep, ideal for isolated locations.
  • Environmentally Friendly: Solar power reduces reliance on diesel generators, lowering carbon emissions and noise pollution.
  • Cost-Effective: After initial installation, solar power has very low running costs.

Beyond conservation, solar power is increasingly being adopted across Africa for various applications, from rural electrification to powering urban infrastructure. This shift towards renewable energy is helping to address energy poverty while promoting sustainable development across the continent.

More about man-made water holes

Man-made waterhole serve as a vital water source and social hub in Savuti. The convergence of different animals at waterholes like Rhinovlei, Pump Pan and Marabu Pan often leads to interesting inter-species interactions and hierarchies. For instance, elephants typically have priority access due to their size and dominance, while other animals must wait their turn or find creative ways to access the water.

The time around sunset is especially active at waterholes, as many animals prefer to drink when temperatures are cooler, reducing the risk of dehydration. This timing also coincides with the return of diurnal species from their daily foraging and the emergence of nocturnal animals, creating a dynamic and diverse wildlife spectacle.

Waterholes play a critical role in the ecosystem beyond providing water. They serve as social hubs where animals exchange information through scent marking and vocalizations. Additionally, the mud around these waterholes is rich in minerals, which many animals, particularly elephants, ingest to supplement their diets.

These artificial water sources, while beneficial, can also impact the local ecosystem. Studies have shown that animal densities tend to decrease with increasing distance from water holes, and body size plays a major role in the distribution of species around artificial water holes. This concentration of wildlife can lead to increased pressure on vegetation and soil near the water sources, potentially altering the landscape over time.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 10, Savuti Afternoon Game Drive (22 June, Day 8 of Safari)
entry.content:
After our thrilling morning game drive and a well-deserved siesta, we were ready to embark on our afternoon adventure in Savuti. With a quick coffee to perk us up, we set off in a northwesterly direction, eager to see what wildlife encounters awaited us.

The Wild Dog Den: A Tale of Tragedy

Our first stop was the wild dog den, about 8 kilometers away. The journey took us a good 30 minutes due to the bumpy terrain. As we approached, Kem (our guide) shared a heart-wrenching story that had unfolded just the day before.

Several lions from the Marsh Pride had discovered the den and killed as many wild dog pups as they could find. The adult wild dogs, outnumbered and outmatched, could only watch helplessly from a distance as their young were decimated.

When we arrived, the aftermath of this tragedy was palpable. A pack of 12 wild dogs rested near the den, their usual playful energy replaced by a mournful alertness. No pups were visible – likely hidden deep within the safety of the den. Kem tells us some pups did survive. The dogs were visibly on edge, jumping at the slightest sound. Even a soft sneeze from me (yes, I was still battling that pesky virus) had them startled and alert, looking around for intruders.

Wild dogs of Savuti

We spent about 30 minutes observing these resilient creatures, their recent loss hanging in the air. It was a somber reminder of the brutal circle of life in the African wilderness.

An alert wild dog

While it's easy to anthropomorphize and view the lions' actions as cruel, it's important to remember that this is simply nature in its raw form. Wild dogs themselves are known for their own brutal hunting techniques, often eating their prey alive. In the bush, it's all about survival and reducing competition, not about mercy. 

The Elusive Leopard: A Fruitless Search

As we made our way back from the wild dog den, we crossed paths with another safari vehicle from the Desert & Delta Savute Safari Lodge. They shared news of a leopard sighting nearby, and Kem immediately set off in pursuit of this elusive cat.

For the next 40 minutes, we scoured the area, our eyes peeled for any sign of spotted fur or a telltale flick of a long tail. Despite our best efforts and Kem's expertise, the leopard remained hidden, blending perfectly into its surroundings.

Luxury vs. Frugality: A Safari for Every Budget

Our encounter with the Savute Safari Lodge vehicle got me thinking about the various ways to experience the African bush. The lodge, with its 12 luxury chalets, represents the high-end of safari accommodations. To put it in perspective, a stay there would cost nearly four times what we paid for our more modest bush camping safari.

As I watched the plush vehicle disappear into the bush, I couldn't help but chuckle to myself. Sure, the idea of a hot shower and a comfy bed sounded appealing after days of camping, but there was something special about our more rugged experience. The closeness to nature, the sense of adventure, and let's be honest, the friendlier price tag, all added up to an experience that felt uniquely ours.

Besides, I mused, unless I win the lotto (see: www.lotto.ie), places like Savute Safari Lodge will remain a dream. But out here, under the vast African sky, with the sounds of the bush surrounding us and the thrill of wildlife sightings just around the corner, I felt like the richest person in the world.

As the sun began to set, we headed towards yet another waterhole. 

Map and driving routes

Notes About Today's Sightings

The Plight of Wild Dogs in Southern Africa

African wild dogs, also known as painted wolves, are facing a critical situation in Southern Africa. Once roaming in packs of hundreds across the continent, their numbers have dwindled alarmingly. Today, it's estimated that only about 6,600 wild dogs remain in the wild, with their range reduced to just 7% of their historical territory.

The main threats to wild dogs include habitat fragmentation, human-wildlife conflict, and diseases such as rabies and canine distemper. Their complex social structure and large territorial requirements make them particularly vulnerable to these pressures. Conservation efforts are underway, but the road to recovery for these charismatic canids is long and challenging.

The Remarkable Hunting Prowess of African Wild Dogs

African wild dogs, despite not being the fastest predators, are among the most successful hunters in the African wilderness. Their hunting strategy is a masterclass in teamwork and endurance:

  • Pack Hunting: hunt in packs, typically 6 to 20 strong, using sophisticated communication and coordination.
  • Endurance Over Speed: rely on stamina rather than raw speed, capable of maintaining speeds up to 35 mph (56 km/h) over long distances.
  • Relay Pursuit: pack members take turns leading the chase, allowing others to conserve energy for a relentless pursuit.
  • Strategic Targeting: often select weaker or smaller prey, improving their chances of success.
  • Efficient Dispatch: they begin consuming their prey almost immediately, sometimes while it's still alive, minimizing the risk of losing their kill to other predators.

This combination of tactics results in an astounding 80% success rate, far surpassing many other predators. While their methods may seem brutal, they represent a finely tuned survival strategy honed over millennia in the unforgiving African savanna.

The Challenge of Tracking Leopards and Cheetahs

Leopards and cheetahs are among the most elusive big cats in Africa, making them a prized sighting for any safari-goer. Their shy nature and excellent camouflage make tracking them a true test of skill and patience.

Leopards are masters of stealth, often resting in trees or dense bush during the day. Their rosette-patterned coats blend perfectly with dappled sunlight, making them nearly invisible even when in plain sight. Cheetahs, while more active during daylight hours, are sparse in number and cover vast territories, making chance encounters rare.

Experienced guides rely on a combination of tracking skills, knowledge of individual animals' territories, and communication with other safari vehicles to locate these cats. Even then, sightings are never guaranteed, which only adds to the excitement when one is finally spotted.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 10, Savuti morning game drive (22 June, Day 8 of safari)
entry.content:
As the first light of dawn painted the Savuti sky, we stirred from our tents, still buzzing from last night's thrilling leopard encounter. The promise of a new day in this wildlife paradise had us eager to see what adventures awaited. Little did we know that we were about to have one of the most memorable mornings of our entire safari.

Our day began with the now familiar routine - up at 5:30 AM followed by a hearty breakfast at 6:15. Shine, our culinary wizard, had whipped up a batch of delicious pancakes to fuel us for the morning's expedition. With full stomachs and high spirits, we climbed into our trusty Land Cruiser, ready to explore the Savuti plains.

The Marsh Pride: Morning on the Plains

Shortly after setting out, we received word of nine members from the renowned Marsh Pride spotted on the plains. This formidable pride, typically numbering around 18 lions, dominates the marshlands of Savuti. A brief 20-minute drive brought us to the sight of two cubs under a year old, four juveniles, and three mature lionesses frolicking in the morning sun.

Our first sight of the marsh pride frolicking in sunlight

A Morning with the Marsh Pride

As the sun climbed higher, warming the chilly morning air, we watched the lions play and frolic. The cubs tumbled over each other, practicing their stalking skills on unsuspecting grass tufts, while the juveniles engaged in mock fights, honing their strength and agility.

But it wasn't all play. As the morning progressed, the lionesses began to eye the herds of tsessebe and zebra grazing nearby. We held our breath as the pride slowly edged closer to their potential prey, their movements a masterclass in stealth and patience.

Watch her body language as she sneaks up on her prey

The hunting attempts that followed were both fascinating and, at times, comical. During one stalk, a juvenile lion was a bit too slow to crouch, inadvertently alerting the antelope to the pride's presence. In another instance, the playful cubs continued their antics when the lionesses were trying to hunt, earning them a stern rebuke from one of the adults.

Lionesses sitting down to minimise exposure. One on the right has not got the memo yet!

It was on their third attempt that we saw real teamwork emerge. Everyone, from the youngest cub to the most experienced lioness, seemed to have gotten the memo. They moved in perfect synchronization, closing in on a group of tsessebe.

Stalking a tsessebe

The tension was palpable as they inched closer... only for the antelope to bolt at the last second, leaving the lions with empty paws and, I imagine, growling stomachs. That a herd of impala were screaming warning calls did not help the lions' cause one bit.

Regrouping after a failed hunt

What made this experience even more special was the solitude. For most of the morning, we were the only vehicle there, allowing us to observe these magnificent creatures in peace, without the disturbance of other safari vehicles jockeying for position.

In the video below, watch how the lions' body language changes when they stalk prey. 


The video below, shows the marsh pride regrouping after a failed hunt. 

One tool that proved indispensable throughout the morning was our pair of 8x42 binoculars. To ensure we didn’t disturb the lions' natural behavior or interfere in their hunt, we often kept at least 100 meters away. The binoculars allowed us to observe the pride’s intricate dynamics and subtle interactions up close, without compromising their environment. The ability to maintain such a respectful distance while still capturing every detail made all the difference, especially during moments of high activity like hunting attempts.

A Well-Earned Rest

After four unsuccessful hunting attempts, the lions finally called it a morning and settled down under the shade of a tree for a well-deserved nap. Taking this as our cue, we slowly made our way back to camp, stopping at the Rhinovlei waterhole for a coffee break and to watch more elephants quench their thirst.

Back at camp, another of Shine's delicious meals awaited us - a lunch of pasta, vegetarian sausages, beans, and a fresh salad. As we ate, we couldn't stop talking about our morning with the Marsh Pride. It was experiences like these that made me eager to learn more, prompting me to purchase "The Lion" by Craig Packer - a fascinating book filled with statistics and insights into the social structure of lion prides.

As I settled down for a siesta, fighting off a virus that had been making its way through our group, I couldn't help but feel a sense of anticipation for our afternoon drive. The promise of visiting a wild dog den had my imagination running wild. Despite feeling under the weather, the wonders of Savuti were proving to be the best medicine.

Stay tuned for our afternoon adventure with Savuti's painted wolves!

Map and driving routes

Notes about today's sightings

Lion Pride Dynamics: Splitting and Social Structures

In large lion prides, it's common for members to split into smaller groups, especially during hunting or territorial patrols. These sub-groups, often consisting of related females and their offspring, operate semi-independently but maintain cohesion through regular reunions. This fission-fusion society allows for efficient resource utilization and flexibility in responding to environmental changes. The social hierarchy within a pride is complex, with dominant individuals leading hunts and younger members learning through observation and participation.

Lion prides of Savuti

The Savuti region is home to two notable lion prides:

  1. The Marsh Pride: With approximately 18 members, this pride is known for its dominance over the Savuti plains and marshlands.
  2. The Northern Pride (also called Channel Pride): Also significant in the Savuti area, though less is known about its current size and dynamics.

The Elephant-Hunting Lions of Savuti and Linyanti

The lions of Savuti and Linyanti gained fame for their unique ability to hunt elephants, a behavior rarely seen elsewhere. This adaptation emerged during periods when the Savuti Channel dried up, leading to a scarcity of typical prey. The Marsh Pride, at its peak, was recorded killing over 30 elephants per year. 

However, with the recent flowing of the Savuti Channel, this behavior has become less common. The increased water has attracted more diverse prey, reducing the lions' reliance on elephant hunting.

Challenges of Hunting in Open Plains

Lions face significant challenges when hunting in open plains like those in Savuti. The increased visibility makes it difficult for them to approach prey undetected. This is why we often see lions hunting at night or during the cooler hours of early morning and late afternoon when they have the advantage of low light.

The failed hunting attempts we witnessed are quite common. Studies show that lions are successful in only about 25% of their hunts, with success rates even lower in open areas. 

Interestingly, during full moon nights, the usual nocturnal advantage of lions diminishes as they remain visible to prey under the bright moonlight. To adapt, lions are more likely to hunt during the day during this lunar phase. Our visit coincided with the waxing moon, reaching its peak as a full moon while we were in Savuti. This celestial timing gave us the unique opportunity to witness heightened lion activity during the day - a rare treat for safari-goers and a testament to the lions' adaptability in challenging conditions.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 9, Savuti evening game drive (21 June, Day 7 of safari)
entry.content:
Content Warning: Graphic Content. Photos of an impala kill below.

After a long day of travel and settling into our campsite in Savuti, we were eager for our first game drive in this renowned part of Botswana. The sun had begun its slow descent when we left for the evening drive, setting the stage for what would turn out to be a truly unforgettable adventure.

Leopard Sighting: A Glimpse into the Wild

Our first stop was guided by the familiar hum of Mobnet chatter - a vital communication network used by safari guides and vehicles to share sightings and ensure safe and coordinated drives across the park. Kem picked up on the chatter barely 5 min into the drive and led us to an extraordinary sighting: a leopard and her cub. While we were expecting a leopard sighting, the real surprise came when we spotted a mother and her cub together, a rare and heartwarming moment that added an extra layer of magic to the evening.

Contently watching her cub eat

The mother had brought down an impala, and we watched in awe as her cub eagerly tore into the carcass, the pair oblivious to the world around them. We stayed with them for about 15-20 minutes, mesmerized by the intimate moment of this powerful predator family.

The cub is busy eating - oblivious to our presence

The leopards were nestled deep in an acacia thicket, making it a bit challenging to get a good view. Only one vehicle could approach at a time, so after a while, we moved on to allow the next group to take their turn.

The cub looks up just as we were about to leave

Sunset at Rhino Pan: A Serenade of the Savuti Wilderness

A tower of elephants - heading to a waterhole

Next, we made our way to the Rhinovlei waterhole for sunset, where the real magic of the African wilderness unfolded before us. The air was thick with the sounds of nature as elephants, jackals, and warthogs gathered around the water.

A jackal tries to get in for a drink amongst the giants

We sat there for a while, soaking in the serenity of the scene. Elephants bathed in the fading sunlight, their dusty grey silhouettes contrasting beautifully with the orange and pink hues of the sky.

Elephants, sunset, waterhole - perfect

As the day closed, we reluctantly packed up and began the drive back to camp, mindful of the 6:30 pm curfew. But the Savuti wildlife had one last gift for us — more elephants, returning from their evening drink as we made our way home. Each sighting felt like a perfect punctuation mark to a day well spent.

Mother and calf head home after a drink


Dinner and Rest: A Well-Earned End to the Day

Back at camp, Shine had prepared another delicious meal: vegetable sausage, homemade bread, salad, and baked beans. As tired as we were from the day’s activities, we had no energy left for campfire stories. Everyone turned in early, ready for another adventure the following day. By 9:30 pm, the camp was silent, save for the distant sounds of the bush.

Up Next: Savuti by Day

Tomorrow, we would experience Savuti in daylight, exploring the rich landscape and wildlife that this incredible part of Botswana has to offer. Stay tuned for more adventures in the heart of the African wilderness!

Map and driving routes

The map below shows the area covered in the evening drive and the locations where we found the leopards and the elephant herds.  

Notes about Today's Sightings

Leopard with Cub: A Lesson in Survival

The leopard sighting was extraordinary, offering a rare glimpse into the intimate relationship between a mother and her cub. Leopards are solitary and territorial, with males occupying larger territories that often overlap with those of several females. The mother allowing her cub to feed first demonstrates the important role of maternal care in leopard society, ensuring the cub develops proper feeding techniques and builds strength.

Cubs typically stay with their mothers for about 18-24 months, during which time they learn crucial hunting and survival skills. This period is vital for the cub's development, as it will eventually need to survive on its own or potentially form coalitions with other young males.

Artificial Waterholes in Savuti: Sustaining the Wild with Solar Power

Savuti's artificial waterholes play a crucial role in supporting wildlife during the dry season. There are three main man-made waterholes in the area:

  • Rhino Pan (also known as Rhinovlei)
  • Pump Pan
  • Marabu Pan (also spelled Marabou)

These waterholes become increasingly important as natural water sources become scarce, attracting a diverse array of wildlife and creating spectacular viewing opportunities for safari-goers.

The implementation of solar-powered pumps to maintain these waterholes is an eco-friendly solution that harnesses the abundant sunlight of the African savanna. This technology ensures a consistent water supply, supporting both herbivores and predators through the harshest dry periods.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 9, Khwai to Savuti (21 June, Day 7 of safari)
entry.content:
Our adventure continued as we bid farewell to Khwai and set off for Savuti, a region renowned for its rugged landscapes and thriving wildlife. The day promised a scenic drive filled with the kind of moments that make this journey through Botswana unforgettable.

Khwai to Mababe Gate: A Gentle Goodbye

We departed Khwai at 11 a.m., with a quick stop to see the lions one last time. They rested in the shade, relaxed and indifferent to the world around them.

One last look at the snoozing lions

And as we watch, they all fall asleep. This is the life. 

Along the Khwai River, we encountered more elephant herds, their deliberate strides and playful interactions capturing the serenity of this stretch of wilderness.

Ninety minutes into our drive, we reached Mababe Gate. Lunch, courtesy Shine, turned out to be another highlight. We set up at a shaded spot and savored the meal while a small group of bull elephants in musth wandered nearby. From a safe distance, we watched their imposing forms navigate the terrain, a reminder of the delicate balance of respect and wonder that defines safari life.

The Mababe Depression: A Window into Timeless Africa

Leaving Mababe Gate behind, we continued on to Savuti via the Mababe Depression, where the scenery shifted dramatically. Grassland stretched as far as the eye could see, punctuated by the occasional termite hill or lone tree. The plains, dotted with acacia and teeming with wildlife, felt both expansive and serene. Antelope grazed in loose herds, giraffes browsed gracefully among the sparse foliage, and elephants moved in their unhurried rhythm. It wasn’t a landscape designed to overwhelm, but its understated beauty had a calming, almost meditative quality. The sheer scale and tranquility of the scene left us in awe – a quintessential African tableau that felt timeless.

Grasslands as far as you can see, termite hills, the odd tree and game grazing. just Africa

As we pressed on, the drive grew longer and dustier, but the wildlife sightings kept our spirits high. More elephants and giraffes crossed our path, their movements adding life to the expansive landscape.

Protection against sun, sand, wind and dust. #dune

Then came an extraordinary sighting: a Verreaux's eagle-owl, roosting quietly in a tree. These elusive giants of the avian world are rarely spotted during daylight hours, making the moment feel all the more special. We stopped to admire the sleeping owl, snapping a few photos to remember the encounter.

Verreaux's eagle-owl. Note the pink eye lids.

Chaitra spotted this well camouflaged owl from a 100 metres away when driving at 60 kmph. Go figure!

Arrival at Boga Site MGR-12: A Home in the Wild

By late afternoon, we arrived at our campsite in Savuti: Boga Site MGR-12. Tucked away in the wilderness, it mirrored the remoteness and charm of our campsite in Moremi. The surrounding silence, punctuated only by the sounds of nature, felt like a warm embrace from the bush.

At the Savuti campsite (boga site mgr-12)

As KG and Shine began setting up camp, we took a moment to freshen up and shake off the dust from the road. The process of watching a campsite come to life never gets old – the steady rhythm of activity as tents are pitched and the fire pit is readied holds a simple but profound satisfaction.

Up Next

With the sun lowering on the horizon, we prepared for our first game drive in Savuti. 

Map and driving routes

The map below outlines our drive from the Khwai campsite to Mababe gate, via Mababe depression, to the BOGA campsite MGR-12. Total driving distance: approximately 90 km.

Notes about today's sighting

Mababe Depression: A Unique Ecosystem

The Mababe Depression, once an ancient lakebed, is now a vast grassland serving as a vital wildlife corridor between Chobe National Park, Moremi Game Reserve, and the Okavango Delta. This dynamic landscape transforms seasonally, becoming a shallow wetland during rains and a sprawling savanna in dry periods.

Its open terrain offers unobstructed wildlife viewing, attracting diverse herbivores and their predators. The depression plays a crucial role in elephant migration, with herds traversing the area between Chobe and Okavango. Waterholes become essential gathering points during dry seasons.

Verreaux's Eagle-Owl: The African Giant

The Verreaux's eagle-owl, or giant eagle owl, is one of Africa's largest owl species, reaching heights of 66 cm with wingspans exceeding 1.5 meters. Distinctive features include pink eyelids and piercing yellow eyes, set against grey, finely-barred plumage that provides excellent camouflage.

These formidable nocturnal predators have a diverse diet, ranging from small mammals to prey as large as small antelopes and monkeys. Their powerful talons and strong beak make them efficient hunters.

Typically nocturnal, daytime sightings are rare. They often roost in dense foliage or tree hollows, remaining motionless for long periods. Monogamous and often mating for life, they nest in large tree cavities or abandoned nests of other birds.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 9, Khwai morning drive (21 June, Day 7 of safari)
entry.content:
Morning Drive Along the Khwai River

Our morning began with the usual routine - up at 5:30 am, enjoying coffee at 6:30 am, and then heading out for our morning game drive at 7 am. As KG and Shine stayed back to break camp, we set off along the Khwai River. Kem drove slowly, allowing us to fully take in the incredible variety of wildlife around us. We saw many a waterbuck and red lechwe. The birdlife in particular, was spectacular, with sightings of open-billed storks, and the majestic fish eagle most common. It was a peaceful, pleasurable drive, made even more special by the diversity of species we encountered.

See the photos below showing some of the wildlife we saw.

Open billed stork

A white backed vulture, a hooded vulture and an egret

Waterbuck

Fish eagle: abundant along the Khwai river

Driving to the lions of Khwai

While we were enjoying our drive along the Khwai River, Kem received a message on MobNet: a pride of lions had been spotted about 10 kilometers from our location. Initially, we agreed to stick to our original plan and continue the drive, but after about 15 minutes, curiosity got the better of me. I asked Kem to take us to see the lions, and what followed was a truly spectacular drive.

We ventured through a landscape dotted with dead leadwood trees, which Kem mentioned are the reason the Magotho campsite got its name. “Magotho” means leadwood in Tswana. 

Dead leadwood forests near Magotho campsite

Along the way, we encountered several large herds of elephants, some of them drinking and playing in the Khwai River, a sight that never fails to captivate.

Elephant herds along khwai river

Watching the Lions

When we finally arrived at the spot, we found four lionesses and a magnificent lion. The lion was clearly courting and guarding one of the lionesses, likely because they were mating. Among all the lions I've seen on this safari, this one was by far the most handsome. I'm truly glad we made the detour to witness this magnificent pride.

We weren’t the only ones who had tracked down the pride. Several self-driving safari goers had found the lions by following another safari vehicle.

A lion with 4 lionesses

As expected at this time of day, around 10 am, the lions were mostly interested in lying in the warm sun and snoozing. We sat quietly, watching them for a good 20 minutes, absorbing the peaceful yet powerful presence of these magnificent creatures (see video below).

4 lionesses and a lion, Khwai river

However, the tranquility was short-lived. One of the self-drivers, seemingly bored of watching the lions doze, decided to stir things up. He opened and closed the side view mirror of his Land Rover a couple of times, causing a whirring sound. 

The lion, roused from his slumber, suddenly stood up, and two of the lionesses became keenly aware of the vehicles around them.

Kem advised us that it was time to move on. He reminded us that safari goers should always remain inconspicuous, as drawing attention from the lions could disrupt their natural behavior - a reminder that our presence in the wild should be as unobtrusive as possible.

On to Savuti

We returned to camp, where KG and Shine had everything packed up and ready to go. It was time to head to our next destination - the Savuti Marshes in Chobe National Park. The 60-kilometer drive would take us through Mababe Gate, where we planned to stop for lunch before continuing to our campsite in Savuti.

Map and driving routes

The map below outlines our morning drive route along the Khwai River (west of the campsite) and the path we took eastward to reach the lion pride.

Note on Safari Etiquette

It's essential for self-driving safari goers to educate themselves on how to behave around wild animals; otherwise, they risk endangering themselves, others, and the very animals they’ve come to see. When in the presence of wildlife, it's crucial to remain quiet and still, avoid sudden movements, and never attempt to provoke a reaction from the animals. Vehicles should maintain a respectful distance and minimize noise, allowing the animals to carry on with their natural behaviors undisturbed. Remember, the goal is to observe, not interfere.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 8, Khwai sun downer and night drive (20 June, Day 6 of safari)
entry.content:
Evening Drive

At about 5:15 pm, we set off for our sundowner, taking a scenic drive along the Khwai River to a beautiful spot approximately 3 km from our campsite. The route was picturesque, with the sun casting a warm glow over the landscape. However, a frequent interruption was the numerous self-drivers stopping Kem to ask if he had seen any lions or leopards - a common occurrence in Khwai. It was a reminder of the challenges self-drivers face in spotting wildlife without the network and expertise of the BOGA community. 

Something Kem said on the drive “Moremi is vast and diverse and you have to work hard to find wildlife. In Khwai, it’s much easier - all the wildlife clusters around the Khwai River.”

Map: Campsite to Sundowner and Back

Sundowner

We spent about an hour at the sundowner spot, where the sky turned a fiery red, reflecting off the river. 

Sundowner with elephants and hippos for company

Elephants drank leisurely from the water, while hippos began to stir, preparing for their night of foraging.

A lone elephant and the setting sun

The scene was so serene and beautiful that words simply can’t do it justice - just look at the photos below.

More elephants against a golden sky

I found a waist-deep hole in the ground that made for a perfect spot to sit and photograph the elephants, giving me a unique perspective.

In my little hole in the ground trying to photograph the elephants against a setting sun

As the sun dipped below the horizon, the temperature dropped swiftly, the warmth of the day giving way to a sudden chill in the air. Mist began to form on the river, creating a ghostly layer over the water. In the background, the grunts of hippos echoed continuously, a reminder of their presence, while the sound of water splashing signaled the elephants taking their last drink of the day before retreating inland. It was a serene yet vibrant moment, full of the subtle sounds and sights of the wild. Time for us to move on - night drive beckons!

The last elephant leaves the Khwai river, and fog starts to form on the river

Elephants and sundowner at Khwai river

Night Drive

After the sundowner, we eagerly set off on our night drive, having heard amazing stories of the nocturnal activity in Khwai. This was supposed to be the highlight of the day, where we might witness predators in action, but unfortunately, it didn’t live up to expectations. Kem seemed uneasy with the night drive, preferring to make it short. He drove with one hand on the steering wheel and the other holding a flashlight, which didn’t inspire much confidence. It also seemed like Kem wasn’t familiar with the best spots for night viewing, and there wasn’t any activity on MobNet either. What we hoped would be an exhilarating experience turned out to be the only disappointment of our entire three-week trip. In hindsight, the lesson here is that night drives in Khwai can yield good results only if you’re well-prepared and your guide has prior experience. Ideally, you need two people - one to drive and another to operate the spotlight. 

We did see 2 interesting sights though: a lone hyena chewing on some old antelope carcass and a crocodile scavenging the remains of a 2 week old elephant carcass. The crocodile slowly emerging from an elephant carcass gave Niharika the chills. So, even the disappointing night drive did have a bright spot or two.

Back to Camp and Sleep

We returned to camp around 9:15 pm, had another lovely dinner (thanks to Shine), and settled in for the night by 10 pm. Unfortunately, I was still feeling under the weather from the virus Chaitra passed on, so I skipped sitting by the campfire and went straight to bed.

Tomorrow...

We head to Savuti marshes after a morning drive in Khwai. 

Notes about today's sightings

Nile Crocodile in Botswana

The Nile crocodile (Crocodylus niloticus) is Africa's largest freshwater predator, commonly found in rivers, lakes, and marshes, including Botswana's Okavango Delta and Chobe River. These formidable reptiles can grow up to 5 meters (16 feet) in length and are known for their powerful bite and ambush hunting techniques. They primarily feed on fish but are opportunistic predators, capable of taking down large prey, including antelope and even young hippos.

Night Safaris in Africa

Night safaris offer a unique opportunity to observe nocturnal wildlife and are particularly rewarding in regions where predators like lions, leopards, and hyenas are most active after dark. The best results for night safaris can be experienced in private reserves and concessions where off-road driving and nighttime activities are permitted. Notable locations include Botswana's Khwai Concession, South Africa's Sabi Sands, and Kenya's Ol Pejeta Conservancy. These areas are known for their diverse wildlife and the chance to witness rare nocturnal behaviors.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 8, Moremi to Khwai (20 June, Day 6 of safari)
entry.content:
Drive to Khwai

After a final, lingering look at our campsite near Moremi's Second Bridge, we packed up and bid farewell to this serene corner of the wilderness by 10 am. Our journey today took us from the heart of Moremi to the Khwai concession. Khwai concession is the only reserve in Botswana that allows night drives which we were very much looking forward to. 

Our route took us from Moremi’s Second Bridge to the South Gate, then through the North Gate, and finally to the Magotho campsite in Khwai. The map below highlights our driving route and wildlife sightings along the way.

Moremi second bridge to Magotho campsite in Khwai: driving map and sightings

This was a long and very bumpy 85 km drive, but the stunning scenery and frequent wildlife sightings made it more than worthwhile.

A pair of black backed jackals; commonly found in monogamous pairs

Bee eater. The camouflage is amazing

A pair of go-away birds

A lone male ostrich

Zebra

Tsessebe, fastest antelope on land

We stopped for a packed lunch at the Moremi North Gate, where we met up with a resupply jeep from Shipungo. The team brought fresh provisions, new linens, and a much-needed spare tire for our trailer.

Khwai First Impressions

Arriving at the Magotho campsite in Khwai, we were met with a rather unexpected and grating atmosphere. The campsite was bustling with the noise of self-driving safari goers - loud music, flashing lights, and large crowds gathered around braai pits. It felt out of place in what we had hoped would be a tranquil, remote safari experience.

We couldn’t help but feel a bit of annoyance, especially after hearing that a leopard, once a regular visitor to this area, had moved away due to the increasing noise and activity. What was once his prime territory now felt overrun, and it was disappointing to see how human presence was impacting the natural order.

The facilities were clean and well-maintained, with two toilets and two shower cubicles - a luxury out here in the bush.

Next Post

We all enjoyed cold water showers and then set off for our sundowner - Kem mentioned he knew a lovely spot along the Khwai River. Stay tuned for the next post: sundowner along the Khwai River and night drive in Khwai.

Notes about today's sightings

Tsessebe

We couldn’t help but chuckle when we first spotted the Tsessebe. With their awkward stance and slightly comical appearance, they looked like the funniest antelope we had ever seen. But don’t let their ungainly looks fool you.

The tsessebe (Damaliscus lunatus) is a large African antelope known for its distinctive reddish-brown coat and swift speed, making it one of the fastest antelopes on the continent, capable of reaching speeds up to 80 km/h. They are often found in open grasslands and floodplains, such as those in Botswana's Moremi Game Reserve and Khwai Concession. Tsessebe are social animals, typically forming herds that consist of females, calves, and a few males. They are grazers, primarily feeding on grasses and are often seen standing alert, scanning for predators.

Bee-eater (Green-and-Yellow Birds in Botswana)

The bee-eaters seen in Botswana are likely the Little Bee-eater (Merops pusillus) or the Swallow-tailed Bee-eater (Merops hirundineus). These birds are characterized by their vibrant green, yellow, and blue plumage. Bee-eaters are skilled hunters, catching insects mid-flight, with bees being a favorite prey. They are often spotted perched on low branches, scanning for food, and are known for their social behavior, sometimes nesting in colonies within sandy banks.

The green and yellow hues of the bee eater are a masterclass in camouflage. Despite Kem pointing it out, it took us a good 30 seconds to actually spot it amidst the bushes. Its colors blend so perfectly with the environment that it’s a small miracle we found it at all.

Go-away Birds

The Grey Go-away Bird (Corythaixoides concolor), common in Botswana, is named for its distinctive call that sounds like "go-away." These birds have a sleek, grey appearance with a prominent crest on their heads. They are often found in woodlands and savannas, feeding primarily on fruits, buds, and flowers. Go-away birds are known for their loud, harsh calls, which they use to alert other animals to potential danger, making them a sort of early warning system in the wild.

Black-backed Jackals

Black-backed jackals (Canis mesomelas) are small, fox-like canines commonly found in Botswana's savannas and grasslands. They are easily recognizable by the black saddle of fur running down their backs, contrasted with their reddish-brown sides. These adaptable predators are opportunistic feeders, hunting small mammals, birds, and insects, and scavenging when the opportunity arises.

Jackals are known for forming lifelong monogamous pairs, a rarity among canines. Both parents are involved in raising their pups, often with help from older offspring, creating a close-knit family unit.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 8, Moremi GR morning drive (20 June, Day 6 of safari)
entry.content:
Our  last day in Moremi. We are off to Khwai today. 

First sightings of the morning: always some antelope

Morning Game Drive

We set off at 7 am for a final game drive in Moremi, while KG and Shine packed up camp.

The final game drive at Moremi felt like the end of a beautiful chapter, one that I wasn't quite ready to close. As we set out that morning, there was a mix of excitement and a hint of sadness in the air. This was our last chance to soak in the raw beauty of Moremi, to feel the pulse of the wild before moving on to our next adventure. The anticipation was palpable, knowing that every moment in this extraordinary place was fleeting.

Kem suspected a leopard was nearby, but despite our efforts, it remained elusive. However, we did spot a variety of birds, including an impressive close-up of a Bateleur. 

Bateleur

However, we were treated to an incredible sight: a breeding herd of elephants, including five young calves less than a year old. The elephants moved with a graceful, deliberate pace, their trunks swinging lazily as they grazed, completely at ease in their natural habitat. The calves were full of playful energy, tripping and pushing each other, while their mothers kept a watchful eye. From their behaviour, their scant reaction to our presence, and lack of any temporal gland secretions, it seemed like this was a happy herd, not in under any distress and so far unaffected by human contact. See the video below for a glimpse of what we saw.

One mother, in particular, stood protectively between us and her calves, ensuring they stayed on their path. Watching the herd dynamics was truly captivating.

Elephant herd with 5 calves (yearlings)

Walk Around the Campsite

Returning to the campsite, we found that KG and Shine needed a bit more time to pack up, so Kem took us on a short walk around the area. We examined various herbivore droppings - buffalo, impala, giraffe, and elephant - learning about the differences between those of ruminating and non-ruminating herbivores. Kem shared that giraffe droppings are unique due to their fall from 1.5 meters, resulting in a dented side and a bulging opposite side upon impact. Interestingly, giraffe calves are also dropped from this height at birth and are up and running within 15 minutes.

Kem also shared some traditional uses of these droppings: elephant dung can be burned as a mosquito repellent or used as fuel, while the steam from boiling impala droppings is inhaled to relieve cold symptoms.

We also explored the various trees surrounding our camp:

  • Wild Sage: Crush its leaves and apply them to your body if you want to mask your scent from animals downwind.
  • Large Fever Berry: The tannins are so toxic that dropping a branch into a waterhole paralyzes all nearby fish. This method of fishing is now outlawed due to its indiscriminate nature.
  • Kalahari Apple Leaf & Large Fever Berry: These trees indicate excessively sandy soil when found in abundance.

This impromptu nature walk provided fascinating insights into the interconnectedness of the local ecosystem and the traditional knowledge that has been passed down through generations. It was a fitting end to our time in Moremi as we prepared to journey to the Khwai Conservation area.

Next, we’re off to Khwai Conservation, excited for what the day will bring!

More photos

A selection of photos from Moremi GR is here. Note that we took close to 3000 photos during the trip and the ones that I am sharing is a curated subset. 

Notes about today's sightings

Other traditional uses for animal droppings in Africa

In African cultures, animal droppings have a variety of uses. For instance, in Kenya, dried cattle dung is mixed with clay to construct houses, providing insulation against heat. Elephant dung is used to create sustainable paper, especially in regions like Sri Lanka and parts of Africa, supporting eco-friendly practices . Additionally, in some rural areas, goat dung is burned as fuel or used in medicinal teas for treating common ailments like colds .

Elephant calves in a happy herd

Elephant calves in a secure and content herd display numerous playful behaviors essential for their growth. They often engage in mock battles, chase one another, and experiment with their trunks by picking up objects, imitating adults. This play is crucial for developing their physical and social skills. The calves' interactions, especially under the protective watch of their mothers and older herd members, reinforce the strong familial bonds that elephants are known for .

Elephant calves discovering the use of their trunks

Elephant calves are born with an underdeveloped sense of how to use their trunks, which contain over 40,000 muscles. Initially, their trunk movements are uncoordinated, often leading to humorous and clumsy attempts to grab objects or even feed. Over time, through play and observation of older elephants, calves learn to use their trunks for essential tasks such as feeding, drinking, and social interaction. This gradual mastery of the trunk is vital for their survival and integration into the herd .

  • Botswana 2024: Day 7 - Moremi Game Reserve (Elevenses)
  • Botswana 2024: Day 7 - Moremi Game Reserve (Buffalo Encounter

Lunch and shower

Remember the virus Chaitra and Niharika had at the start of our safari? Well, it's finally caught up to me. Thankfully, at least they are back to full health. 

Feeling like death warmed over, I thought a long, hot bucket shower might help - thankfully, KG obliged. Despite my best efforts, I’m still under the weather, but at least I’m clean! (Check out the video below for our bush shower setup.)

Evening Game Drive

After our extended morning drive, we set out again at 4:30 pm. The evening was serene, a welcome change of pace. We paused at a waterhole to watch some hippos lounging about. Further on, we found a peaceful spot to watch the sun dip below the horizon, silhouetting a lone bull elephant as it browsed. 

A lone bull elephant browses against the red evening sky

Just as we were about to head back, we caught wind of a nearby leopard sighting. We eagerly searched but found only a lone hyena, which we followed until it disappeared into the bush.

Last sighting of the day: a lone hyena

Dinner and Bedtime

As the sun dipped below the horizon, signaling the end of our peaceful evening drive, we made our way back to camp. The quiet of the evening settled in, and with it, the comforting thought of a warm meal waiting for us. After a morning full of excitement, the quiet afternoon was quite the welcoming contrast.

Dinner was a comforting homemade cottage pie with pudding and custard for dessert. Shine outdid himself yet again. Exhausted, I headed to bed early, lulled by the sounds of the African night. Tomorrow, we’re up early and off to the Khwai Conservation area—a new adventure awaits.

Routes and sightings

A note on bush shower

I was a little skeptical about the practicality of a bush shower. I was using baby wipes to wash up each day as an alternative to a bush shower. But the shower today changed my mind. From now on, bush shower every other day it is!

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 7, Moremi GR, buffalo kill site (19 June, Day 5 of safari)
entry.content:
Content Warning: Graphic Content. Photos of a buffalo kill below.

Continuing with our story from the last post... off to the kill site at old BOGA site 11.

Wildebeest - on the way to the kill site

Buffalo Herd Encounter

About 5 km before reaching the old BOGA site 11, we came across a large, restless herd of buffalo. The buffalo were visibly on edge, with the males eyeing us warily. It seemed likely that this was the herd that had lost one of its members to the lion pride. 

Large buffalo herd. A male buffalo looks on. They just lost a mate to the lions.

Kem, ever cautious, kept the engine running and an exit route planned - being in the way of a 900 kg charging buffalo was not on the agenda. After 15 minutes of observing the herd, we moved on.

Buffalo Kill Site

Arriving at the old BOGA site 11, we were greeted by the unmistakable smell of fresh meat and blood - there lay the carcass of a large male buffalo, weighing around 800-900 kg.

Our first view of the kill site

Flies buzzed thickly in the air as we approached the scene. We counted nine lions around the kill, some feeding, others resting. This group, likely part of a larger pride, consisted mainly of juvenile lions with a couple of lionesses. The absence of mature males was noticeable, with the juvenile males nearing the age when they would be expelled from the pride.

Driving away the buzzing flies

For these young lions, bringing down such a large buffalo was a significant achievement. 

Watching the scene unfold, I was torn between two conflicting emotions. On one side was the buffalo herd, restless and clearly anguished by the loss of one of their own. I felt their distress, the raw grief of losing a comrade. Yet, on the other side, there was the young lion pride - driven by the need to hunt for survival, with the (soon to be expelled) juveniles learning crucial life skills. I found myself both sorry for the buffalo and quietly cheering for the lions. It was a complex, bittersweet moment that’s hard to fully articulate.

We spent over an hour at the site, observing the lions as they alternated between feeding and resting. 

Not everyone is full yet

The camaraderie within the pride was evident, making the experience even more remarkable. 

Lion pride camaraderie

The best part? We had the scene entirely to ourselves - just the nine lions, the buffalo, and us. In any other place, like Tanzania or Kenya, we would have been vying for space with 20 other vehicles. This intimate opportunity to witness wildlife in such an unspoiled setting is what makes safari in Botswana so extraordinary.

One last look at the resting lions and we move on

See the video below - a 11-minute recording of the lions feeding on the buffalo.

Parting thoughts

As we left the scene, I was reminded of the delicate balance that sustains life in the wild. Every creature plays a role, each action rippling through the ecosystem in ways both visible and unseen. The loss of one life feeds another, and in this cycle, the interconnectedness of nature is laid bare. It’s a humbling reminder that in the wild, survival is a shared story, one that binds all living beings in a web of interdependence.

Routes and sightings

See the map below showing all the sightings from the morning drive on the 19th. The buffalo kill site at the old BOGA camp site 11 is to the northwest of third bridge.

Notes about our midday sightings

Risks and challenges when encountering a buffalo herd

Buffaloes, especially males, can be highly unpredictable and aggressive, particularly when they feel threatened or if a predator is nearby. A charging buffalo, weighing up to 900 kg, can be extremely dangerous. Safari guides like Kem often keep the engine running and plan an escape route when near a herd to ensure a quick getaway if necessary. Observing the herd's behavior closely is essential, as their body language can indicate whether they feel threatened or aggressive.

The success of young lions in bringing down a buffalo

For juvenile lions, successfully bringing down a large prey like a buffalo is a considerable achievement, as it demonstrates their growing hunting skills and strength. This ability is crucial as they approach the age when they will be expelled from the pride and need to survive on their own or form coalitions with other young males.

The absence of mature males at the kill site might well indicate that the residents males are a coalition and are residents in more than one pride at the same time. Male lion coalitions, especially those dominating two prides, spend a limited amount of time with each pride - around 15% with each. The rest of their time, approximately 70%, is spent patrolling their vast territory, marking boundaries, and fending off rival male lions. Their frequent absence means that the lionesses must often hunt and protect the cubs on their own.

The time spent with the prides can also vary depending on the environment. In areas with dense vegetation, where threats are harder to detect, males may spend even less time with the prides, focusing more on patrolling and defending the territory from potential intruders.

Large lion prides and their dispersal

In large lion prides, it’s not uncommon for the pride to be spread out across different areas. Lions may split into smaller groups to cover more territory or because of the availability of prey. This flexibility allows the pride to manage resources more effectively and reduces the competition for food among members.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 7, Moremi GR, elevenses at dead tree island (19 June, Day 5 of safari)
entry.content:
Continuing with our story from the last post... off to the dead tree island

Dead tree island, here we come

Lion creche at the Dead Tree Island

Continuing from our morning adventures, we set our sights on Dead Tree Island, a place Kem had visited four weeks ago where he saw two lionesses moving their cubs. He estimated the cubs would now be between 8 and 12 weeks old, so we set off on a 15 km drive, arriving at Dead Tree Island by 9:15 AM.

Once again, the mobnet chatter proved invaluable as Kem quickly zeroed in on the location of the lionesses. We arrived at a thicket and found a creche with two nursing lionesses and six cubs. 

Lioness looks up at a newly arriving safari vehicle

As the second vehicle on the scene, we secured a prime viewing spot. The cubs nursed, and after they had their fill, they vanished into the thicket. The lionesses, paying little attention to us, lounged in the warm sun, while the cubs curiously observed us. 

A cub looks up at us before trotting off into the bush

We spent a good 20 minutes watching the creche before moving on when the cubs disappeared into the bush.

A solitary lion

Barely 250 meters from the lionesses, we spotted a solitary lion and decided to move over to watch him. He appeared to be an aging lion, also enjoying a snooze. Kem explained that this lion wasn’t part of the pride but hung around to scavenge leftover scraps from the pride’s hunts. Given the risk of infanticide by outside males, we were surprised the lionesses tolerated his presence, especially with such young cubs. 

Solitary lion hanging around close to the creche

We watched the lion for a while, but as he seemed uninterested in our presence, we decided to move on.

Elevenses at Dead Tree Island

After more than three hours of our morning drive, we decided it was time for a break. We found a spot about a kilometer away, next to a small lake, to enjoy our elevenses: coffee and biscuits. 

Elevenses at the dead tree island. Chaitra and Niharika pose. Vintage.

While we were there, we witnessed just how challenging self-driving in Moremi can be. At least three self-drivers approached Kem for directions to the lionesses, and although Kem kindly obliged, they were still unable to find the lions.

On the Trail of More Lions

Just as we were getting ready to move on, we encountered another safari vehicle. The guide informed Kem of a young pride that had brought down a buffalo, located at the old BOGA (Botswana Guides Association) campsite 11. Not many people know this location, but Kem does. With that, Kem suggested we head to the kill site, though he cautioned us not to get our hopes too high - Moremi is vast, and finding the lions might not be easy.

Elephants on the Way

The old BOGA site 11 is 8 km as the crow flies, but it’s closer to 20 km by road. As we continued toward the old BOGA site, about 2 km into our drive, we encountered a breeding herd of elephants slowly crossing the road, browsing, and drinking water. We paused to observe the peaceful scene.

Suddenly, the atmosphere shifted. From behind the bushes, the matriarch came charging out with purpose. Her powerful stride commanded attention as she assessed our presence, shook her head, then stomped over to her family. 

The matriarch comes rushing, shakes her head at us...

And stomps over to her family

Within moments, the herd, now organized and alert, marched off in a single file, trunks raised, sniffing the air. It was a commanding display of leadership and unity - a sight I had never witnessed before.

The herd is now off in a single file, trunks up, smelling the air

As the elephants disappeared off into the flood plains, we continued our journey - but not before we had spotted a lone, very elusive serval. 

Routes and sightings

See the map below showing all the sightings from the morning drive on the 19th. The location where we found the creche with 2 lionesses, 6 cubs and a solitary lion at dead tree island is to the north east of the third bridge.

Coming next

The kill site!

Notes about our morning sightings

Lion creches

A lion creche is a grouping of cubs from different mothers within a pride, often cared for by multiple lionesses. These lionesses may nurse and protect each other's cubs, providing a communal effort in raising the young. This social structure allows lionesses to hunt while ensuring the cubs are looked after. Creches strengthen the bonds within the pride and increase the survival rate of the cubs by offering more consistent care and protection from predators.

Matriarch in an elephant breeding herd

The matriarch in an elephant breeding herd is the oldest and often most experienced female. She leads the herd, making critical decisions about movement, feeding, and protection. The matriarch uses her knowledge of the terrain and resources to guide the herd to water and food sources. Her leadership ensures the safety and cohesion of the group, especially in times of danger. The younger elephants rely on her guidance, and her presence is crucial for the herd's survival and social structure.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 7, Moremi GR, morning drive (19 June, Day 5 of safari)
entry.content:
We woke up at 5:45 am to the cool, pre-dawn air of Moremi Game Reserve. By 6:30 am, we were warming up with coffee and rusks, readying ourselves for the day's adventure. This is going to be a lion of a day - we just don't know it yet. 

Our Morning Drive Begins

Our morning drive began like most others, with the usual sightings of antelope. The red lechwe, bathed in the golden hues of the rising sun, looked especially beautiful. We spent a good ten minutes watching a lone bull elephant, his massive form a majestic sight against the dawn light.

Bull elephant up close

First Lion Sighting

Suddenly, there was chatter on the mobnet radio, and Kem started driving like a man on a mission. After 20 minutes of this F1 safari, we arrived at a spot where two male lions were resting. We were second on the scene and got a great viewing spot.

2 male lions resting: this one has fresh wounds on his hind quarters

These were visibly young lions with not very mature manes. One had fresh wounds on his hindquarters, either from a fight or a hunt. Kem mentioned these two lions are usually seen with a lioness, but she wasn’t around today. We watched them for about 30 minutes. They were alert, reacting to the slightest sound, not the typical snoozy lions we expected to see during the daytime. Their reaction when an elephant herd passed by was quite interesting. They seemed ready to bolt if the elephant herd turned their way.

2 male lions resting: keenly watching the elephant herd

Routes and sightings

See the map below showing all the sightings from the morning drive on the 19th. The location where we found the two lions is east of the third bridge.

Next: dead tree island

Content with having watched the two lions for about 30 minutes, Kem suggested we head to Dead Tree Island next. Apparently, two lionesses there have 3-4 week-old cubs, and he hoped to find the pride with the cubs. 

Stay tuned... 

Notes about this morning

Nomadic life of young lions

Young male lions, after being kicked out of their pride, often lead nomadic lives. They may form coalitions with other males, sometimes their brothers, to increase their chances of survival. Together, they roam vast territories, honing their hunting skills and gaining strength. Their ultimate goal is to take over a pride by challenging and overthrowing the resident male(s). This process is dangerous and challenging, but successful males secure their lineage by gaining access to the females in the pride.

Navigating Moremi: Challenges of Self-Driving

Moremi's diverse landscape is a maze of floodplains and unpredictable roads. We saw quite a few self-driving safari goers, but they seemed to struggle to spot lions. A couple of self-drivers saw us racing from the third bridge to the lion location and followed us. They were the only ones who managed to watch the lions. Without mobnet radio and the local knowledge of pro safari guides, self-driving can be quite challenging. In Botswana, we are unlikely to take the self-drive option.

Second and Third Bridge, Moremi GR

These are literally the second and third log bridges across the Sekiri River after entering Moremi from South Gate. They are a notable feature for both guided and self-driving safaris, marking important routes through the park. 

For more information about the campsite at the third bridge, check out this TripAdvisor review.

Second bridge, Moremi GR

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 6, Moremi GR, afternoon drive (18 June, Day 4 of safari)
entry.content:
Afternoon Pursuit

Our afternoon game drive was scheduled to start at 3:30 PM. Just as we were setting off, we heard chatter on the radio about a cheetah pair spotted roughly 5 km away. Excitedly, we spent the next two hours trying to track them down. We found fresh paw prints twice, but the elusive cheetahs remained out of sight for the duration of the drive. Unfortunately, we didn’t spot a single cheetah throughout the entire trip.

On the bright side, we did see more birdlife, as well as more elephants and antelope. A highlight of this part of the drive was spotting two pairs of tawny eagles.

We encountered another safari vehicle whose passengers mentioned seeing a pair of lions and a leopard dragging her kill up a tree. However, luck was not on our side as we didn't spot these animals either.

Leopard Encounter

By 5:30 PM, after what had been a relatively quiet day, I suggested we head to the nearest water hole and watch for any animals coming to drink over the next 30 minutes. We arrived at the water hole and quietly observed a hippo pod preparing to leave the water for the night. Just two minutes later, Kem said, "Listen... a leopard call." We all listened intently for 30 seconds before setting off in a hurry.

We drove for 500 meters and stopped again to listen. With the direction of the leopard call confirmed, Kem drove more cautiously. Five minutes later, we spotted a leopard on his territory patrol. We tracked him for the next 10 minutes until he vanished into the bush. However, we noticed a red lechwe keenly tracking the leopard, so Kem started tracking the lechwe. Two minutes later, we heard sharp alarm calls from nearby impalas. Kem knew they had also spotted the leopard.

Leopard up close. He is on his territory patrol.

A five-minute drive later, following the calls from the impala, Kem found the leopard again, who seemed quite annoyed by the impalas' warning calls. We followed the leopard slowly, maintaining a 20-meter distance for the next 15 minutes until he finally disappeared into the tall golden grass in the afterglow of the sunset.

He disappears off into the tall golden grass

Route and Sightings

For a better idea of our afternoon drive, check out the map linked below. We covered a smaller area than the morning drive but did a lot of back and forth trying to find the cheetah pair.

Return to Camp and dinner

As the sun set, we started back to camp. We stopped for a lovely picture of a giraffe silhouetted against the setting sun. Dinner included potatoes, butternut squash, and vegetable kebabs, followed by a delicious homemade sponge cake. We enjoyed some whiskey and then headed to bed, lulled by the now familiar sounds of the African bush.

Sunset in Moremi

Next Post

Stay tuned for the details of Day 2 in Moremi...

PS: find more photos from the day here. 

Notes about today's sightings

Elusive cheetah

Cheetahs are elusive primarily due to their excellent camouflage and solitary nature. Their tan coat with black spots helps them blend into the tall grasses of the savanna, making them difficult to spot. Additionally, cheetahs tend to avoid areas with high densities of larger predators like lions and hyenas, which can make them more challenging to locate during a safari.

Tawny Eagles

Tawny eagles exhibit fascinating behaviors: lifelong mating pairs and cooperative hunting. They are apex predators and hunt small mammals, birds, and reptiles.

Differences between tracking a leopard and a cheetah in the wild

Tracking a leopard involves looking for signs like claw marks on trees, as leopards often climb to survey their territory or stash their kills. They are nocturnal and secretive, often found in dense vegetation or up in trees. Cheetahs, on the other hand, are more likely to be found in open savannas. They rely on speed for hunting, so their tracks might lead across more open ground. Leopards are generally more adaptable to different environments, while cheetahs prefer specific habitats with fewer larger predators.

Red lechwe and impala behavior in the presence of predators

Red lechwes are highly vigilant and often alert to the presence of predators. Their behavior, such as standing still and watching intently in one direction, can indicate the presence of a predator like a leopard. Impalas do the same too.

When they detect danger, they emit sharp alarm calls to warn other animals of the threat, which can be a useful signal for trackers and safari guides.

Video of the leopard we were tracking

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 6, Moremi GR, morning drive (18 June, Day 4 of safari)
entry.content:
Morning Safari Drive

Rising with the sun, we set off from camp at 7:00 AM for our morning game drive. Our journey began with sightings of elephants, giraffes, and a variety of antelope, including zebras, impalas, kudus, and our first tsessebe—the fastest antelope on land, capable of reaching speeds up to 90 km/h.

We spent a significant time observing a breeding herd of elephants, an awe-inspiring sight that truly captures the essence of the wild. As we continued, birdwatching became a highlight. We encountered a few kori bustards, Botswana's national bird, which is an apex predator in its environment. The kori bustard is known for its impressive size and strength, hunting small mammals, insects, and reptiles​​. The fish eagles are abundant in Moremi, while the lilac-breasted roller bird dazzled us with its stunning colors.

Among other birds, we saw francolins, a lot of other land fowl, a pair of tawny eagles (noted for their lifelong mating), and a bateleur eagle. The starlings and red-billed hornbills are the most commonly seen birds in Moremi GR. We were reminded of Zazu from The Lion King each time we saw the hornbills on their short flights—a couple of flaps of the wings and a glide to the next bush.

The morning seemed quieter compared to previous days, and around noon, we decided to head back to camp. On the way, we stopped at a waterhole to watch a few ostriches. Two females were sand bathing to rid themselves of parasites. Male ostriches have black feathers, while females sport brown ones.

Midday Respite

Back at camp, for lunch, enjoyed skewered vegetables, guacamole, vegan sausages, beans, and homemade bread. It turns out our man Shine is quite adept at baking in ground ovens, which added a delightful rustic touch to our meal. After lunch, Chaitra and Niharika played cards while I caught up on writing my travel diary.

Post lunch relaxation: cards, diary, beer

Route and Sightings

For a better idea of our morning drive, check out the map linked below. It highlights the area covered, from our camp near the Second Bridge to the lion sighting spot during our Moremi day trip—a total distance of nearly 50 km. We're starting to understand why safari isn't recommended for those with bad backs!

Coming Up Next

Stay tuned for the details of our afternoon drive!

Some notes about what we saw

Elephants

In the breeding herd of elephants, we observed several unique behaviors. The matriarch led the group, and the younger elephants stayed close to their mothers for protection. The elephants showed strong social bonds, frequently touching each other with their trunks as a form of communication and reassurance. 

Kori bustard

Kori bustards, being apex predators in their environment, primarily hunt small mammals, insects, and reptiles. Unlike many other large birds that might rely more on scavenging, kori bustards actively hunt their prey. Their hunting style involves walking slowly and methodically through grasslands, using their keen eyesight to spot and catch prey. In comparison, birds like eagles and vultures might soar to find food or rely on scavenging dead animals.

Kori bustard

Ostriches

Ostrich sand bathing is a crucial behavior for their hygiene and health. By rolling and kicking up sand, ostriches dislodge parasites and clean their feathers. This behavior also helps to remove dead skin cells and maintain their plumage. Sand bathing can serve as a social activity among ostriches, with multiple individuals often participating together, which reinforces social bonds within the group. 

Sandbathing ostrich

Lilac breasted roller birds

The lilac-breasted roller is renowned for its acrobatic aerial displays during the breeding season. These displays involve intricate twists, turns, and dives, showcasing their agility and grace. They are monogamous and often mate for life, performing spectacular courtship flights to attract their mates. These birds are also highly territorial and will fiercely protect their nest sites from intruders, often performing dramatic swoops and using their wings to subdue prey. Lilac-breasted rollers predominantly feed on insects but will also eat small lizards and rodents, often hunting from high perches like treetops or telephone poles. During brush fires, they exhibit clever tactics by hunting the insects fleeing from the flames​.

Lilac breasted roller
