entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 5, Okavango Delta to Moremi Game Reserve (17 June, Day 3 of safari)
entry.content:
Wake-Up Call from the Wild

We woke up to the powerful sound of a lion's call, a thrilling reminder of where we were. The lion, seemingly on patrol, was barely 50 meters from our campsite, which added a pulse of excitement to the morning. If you're curious about what a lions call on patrol sounds like, you can listen to it here. By 06:45, we were ready and, after a quick coffee, set off on a brief walk near the campsite. We spotted some magnificent birds, antelopes, hippos, and elephants. Check out the video from our morning walk below.


After returning to the campsite, we had a quick breakfast and then made our way to the mokoro station. Kem was supposed to pick us up at 10 AM, but due to some last-minute jeep repairs, he arrived at 11:15 instead. Our vehicle for the next eight days was an open Land Cruiser with a trailer for our camping gear. Alongside Kem was our camp hand, KG.

It was noon by the time we loaded the trailer. With a heartfelt farewell to Orphan, Case, Steve, and Mentle, we set off for our next destination: Moremi game reserve. We will camp deep in the Moremi game reserve for the next 3 nights. 

What's in a Name?

Remember by previous blog post where I spoke of Tswana names and the English translations of their names? So, naturally we were interested in finding out more about the names of Kem, Shine and KG.  

Kem, whose full name is Keemetseng, told us that his name means "what are you waiting for." Google Translator, however, suggested it means "represented." We'll believe Kem over Google.

Shine's Tswana name is Phatsimo - means "sparkle," but he prefers to be called Shine. So, Shine it is.

KG is short for Kalago, meaning "cured now" or "that's right."

Traveling Light in the Delta

It is necessary to travel light on any safari. No luggage with metal frames is allowed, only soft bags. We brought one duffel bag and one backpack per person. When traveling by mokoro to some remote island on the delta, it's necessary to trim down the luggage even further. When coming to the Okavango delta, we brought only our backpacks with enough clothes for two days and two nights and left our duffel bags with Mark at his Shipungo Travels office.

As we reached the Maun-Moremi main road, we met Mark, who kindly brought our duffel bags and a fresh set of laundered clothes.

Journey to Moremi

With our duffel bags securely loaded, we headed towards the Moremi South Gate. We paused for a quick lunch of pasta and salad, beautifully prepared by Shine. After a brief stop at the Moremi South Gate for Kem to check in and pay the park fees, we continued our journey.

The road to the Second Bridge in Moremi Game Reserve was quite rough, a true back-breaking experience. Midway, one of the trailer tires burst, causing a significant delay as we replaced it.
The journey was filled with sightings of impala, kudu, zebra, elephants, and giraffes. Near our campsite, we had the rare pleasure of watching a pair of honey badgers and a lone hyena.

Honey badger

A lone hyena

We arrived at our campsite around 6 PM. It was a breathtakingly beautiful location - secluded, serene, wild, and a tad bit scary. While Shine and KG set up camp, we went for a short drive as the sun set. In those brief 30 minutes, we didn’t see much, but we got a sense of what to expect for the next three days in Moremi.

Okavango delta to Moremi GR second bridge camp site

Zooming in will show you how isolated the campsite is. The closest human being to us was 7 km away at the third bridge campsite. 

Dinner and Campfire Stories

After dinner (couscous and vegetables), we gathered around a campfire, enjoying stories from Kem with a whiskey in hand. (Yes, I brought a bottle of Johnnie Walker Black Label for such occasions.)

Kem repeatedly made the point that we are at the mercy of nature when it comes to wildlife viewing. Moremi game reserve is spread over 5000 sq. km and there is simply no guarantee that the wild life will show up where we choose to go on a particular day. He was delighted when it was clear that we did not need such explanation and we knew that you could go on a week's safari and still not see the animals you want to see. 

Of the several stories Kem shared that evening, the story that stood out for me was that of a jeep full of tourists throwing píng guǒ (apples) at a pride of lions who were sleeping the afternoon off. Apparently the tourists wanted the lions to stand up for better photos. I was dumbfounded that people come to a safari and exhibit such ignorant behaviour. 

We retired to our tents, falling asleep to the symphony of the African night - hyena calls, occasional lion roars, and the incessant chirping of insects. The waxing moon added an extra touch of beauty to the night.

Looking forward to what tomorrow brings.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 4 afternoon, Okavango Delta (16 June, Day 2 of safari)
entry.content:
Continuing on from Day 4, Okavango Delta (16 June, Day 2 of safari)...

Sun Downer

After a refreshing cup of tea and biscuits back at the camp, we set out for a quintessential safari experience - a sundowner. Equipped with a cooler filled with soft drinks and beers, we hopped into two mokoros. Chaitra, Niharika, and Orphan were in one, while Steve and I were in another.

On our way to the sun downer

On our way to the sundowner (Niharika)

As we glided along the water, we encountered an array of wildlife. We paused to marvel at hippos wallowing in the shallows, buffalo grazing near the banks, and various antelope darting through the underbrush. The birdlife was equally impressive, with storks, herons, cranes, pelicans, and a majestic fish eagle perched on a stump, intently watching the water for its next meal.

Open billed stork looking for snails

Our destination was a small island where we met another couple, Mark and Jen. They’re retirees slow-traveling through Africa over four months—a dream of mine someday. Coincidentally, they were the same people who had the thrilling encounter with eight lionesses that morning. We exchanged stories over drinks, admiring the breathtaking sunset that painted the sky in hues of orange and pink.

Sundowner with [left to right] Niharika, Steve (with a Michael scott paper company jumper), Chaitra, Orphan, Kiran.

Hippo Encounter

After the sun dipped below the horizon and a beer later, we began our journey back to camp. As we passed a pod of hippos, the dominant male grew curious about us. One moment he was submerged, and the next, he was glaring at us from just ten meters away.

Dominant male split from his harem to come glare at us

Despite their usual calm demeanor, Orphan and Steve sped up our mokoro considerably. Their quick reaction was telling - these men, unafraid to track elephants and lions on foot, clearly respected the unpredictable nature of a hippo. I barely had time to snap a photo before we were safely past.

A map of the mokro trip we took is below with hippo and buffalo locations added.

End of Day and Prep for Tomorrow

Dinner at camp was a hearty spread of rice, vegetable stew, and green beans. Shine is a fab chef. Afterward, we gathered around the campfire for stories. Orphan shared how a mistranslation of his Tswana name led to his English name, Orphan.

Before coming to Africa, I watched the NatGeo film Into the Okavango. It turns out Orphan was part of the crew, assisting the drone and helicopter team. The main guide in the film, Water, is Orphan’s first cousin - a small world indeed.

As we prepared for the next leg of our journey, we packed up and planned for a quick morning walk before heading to the mokoro station. There, we’ll meet Kem, our guide for the next eight days.

Once again, we fell asleep to the sounds of the African night - hippo grunts and hyena calls echoing through the darkness.

More photos

More photos from the 2 days in the Okavango delta are in an album here. 

Up Next

Our journey continues from the Okavango Delta to Moremi National Park. Stay tuned!

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 4, Okavango Delta (16 June, Day 2 of safari)
entry.content:
Content Warning: Graphic Content. Photo of a buffalo kill below.

Story so far:

  • Dublin to Botswana
  • Day 1, Maun (13 June)
  • Day 2, Moremi Game Reserve Day Trip (14 June)
  • Day 3, Okavango Delta (Day 01 of the safari): morning adventures, evening chronicles. 

Morning Madness and a Buffalo's Moan

The morning started with a bleary-eyed hustle as Chaitra and Niharika, still battling their pesky safari virus, finally emerged at the leisurely hour of 7:30 AM. A quick cup of tea and some rusks for breakfast, and we were ready for our morning walking safari. Our plan was to head west from camp and check out the local talent. Little did we know, the bush had a surprise in store for us.

Just as we were about to set off, we heard the low moan of a buffalo—the unmistakable sound of a kill (all those years of watching NatGeo paying off!). Orphan, in his inimitable style, said, "Listen... a kill!" The sound originated from the east. And just like that, a new plan formed. "We have heard something interesting just now—and we are going to check it out," declared Orphan.

Close Encounter with the Lions

Another briefing by Orphan (in a straight line, stay close, and all that) and we headed east. Tracking a lion pride on foot was daunting, but Orphan and Steve's confidence reassured us. As Orphan put it, "Elephants, lions - once you know their behavior, you know how to be safe around them... hippos - well, they are the only animals that scare us."

We spent the next two hours searching for the kill site. We heard lions growling, so we knew we were close but had no luck. Just as we were about to give up and head back, we saw another group hurrying towards us—a couple and their guide. They had quite the story.

They too had been looking for the kill site and stumbled upon eight lionesses. In their words, "Scary, hungry-looking, roared at us, we ran, and they darted off in the opposite direction." The last thing one should do in front of a predator is turn their back and run! It triggers their predatory instincts.

Orphan’s reaction was surprising: "Now we know where the kill is... let's go." Despite our fear, his calmness reassured us. We were now a party of eight: Orphan leading, followed by Chaitra, Niharika, me, Steve, the couple, and their guide bringing up the rear.

After another 20 minutes of carefully tracking lion paw prints, we suddenly came upon three lionesses in a clearing. They looked at us, counted us - one, two, three - and darted off into the bush. Orphan explained that when lions see a large group of humans, they perceive us as a single large body and bolt.

Since we were focused on watching our every step and surroundings, there were no photos!

The Kill Site and Tracking Lions

Content Warning: Graphic Content. Photo of a buffalo kill below.

When we encountered the three lionesses was the only time I saw Orphan's calmness give way to some annoyance. Apparently, we were not walking close enough to him. He repeated, slightly annoyed, "When I say stay close, I mean close - only one step behind me."

Now that the lionesses had bolted into the wild sage bushes, we proceeded even more carefully. Five more minutes of tracking led us to the kill site. The lions had taken down a male buffalo and dragged him to a secluded spot under a few trees. But there were no lions to be seen—they had barely started to feed.

Sadly, they had been downwind from us while we were tracking them, caught our scent, and scattered. Orphan warned, "Don't be fooled - they are close by and are watching us. Everyone stay close."

We approached the kill and examined it up close. I expected the smell of blood and freshly cut meat, but what I forgot was that the buffalo eat a lot of grass. The grass had spilled out of its gut. All I could smell was the sweet scent of fresh-cut grass. The juxtaposition of this sweet smell with the sight of a dead buffalo was morbid.

Buffalo kill, Okavango delta

We slowly moved away from the kill, found a high spot, and decided to wait for the lions to return. As we scouted the area with our binoculars, we realized that just as we were tracking the lions, they were tracking us. About 500 meters away, a lioness sat on a termite hill, watching us. Goosebumps!

Sadly, no photos - lions were too far away for my 55-250mm camera lens.

After waiting and circling the area for another two hours, we decided to head back to camp. The plan was to return in the afternoon to see if the lions had come back. If they did, they would have feasted on the buffalo and would likely be drowsy and lounging around the kill, giving us a chance to watch them closely.

Back to the Kill Site: A Clue in the Tracks

We made it back to camp by noon, where Shine had whipped up another fabulous lunch (veg quiche and beans). After a quick rest, we headed back to the buffalo kill site, hoping for another glimpse of the lions. But alas, no such luck. The scene was exactly as we'd left it in the morning, with no sign of the lions returning for their feast. However, we made an interesting discovery: the lion paw prints were imprinted right on top of our shoe prints from the morning. This meant that the lions had returned to the kill site after we had left at midday. Yet, for reasons unknown, they did not stay. Perhaps they were disturbed, or maybe the midday heat was too intense even for these formidable predators.

Orphan mentioned that they might come back later in the evening or at night to feed on the carcass, but sadly, we'd be leaving for Moremi Game Reserve early the next morning. No second chances this time. Lesson learned: when we come back here, we'll plan to spend at least five days in the delta, not just two!

For now, we return to camp and plan something else for our last evening in the Okavango Delta.

Area covered when tracking the lions and the buffalo kill on foot

Up next

A sundowner in the Okavango delta.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 3 afternoon, Okavango Delta (15 June, Day 1 of safari)
entry.content:
Continuing on from Day 3, Okavango Delta (15 June, Day 1 of safari)...

Close Encounter with the Elephants

As I settled down to write in my diary, Orphan, alerted by Steve's return from scouting, turned to me with a glint in his eye.

"Fancy seeing some elephants up close?" he asked. 

With Chaitra and Niharika still napping, it was just the three of us: Orphan, Steve, and myself, ready for our first walking safari in the Okavango delta.

Orphan laid down some ground rules for walking safari. We were to walk single file, with him in the lead, me (and anyone else in the party) close behind, and Steve bringing up the rear as our "backup guide."  We were to step only where Orphan had stepped to minimize noise - the last thing we wanted was to startle a herd of elephants with a snapping twig! And these rules were to be strictly followed for all walking excursions over the next 2 days. 

Briefing complete, we set off - the air thick with the earthy, herbaceous scent of wild sage. "If you're upwind of animals you are tracking and want to mask your scent," Orphan explained, "crush a handful of sage leaves and rub them on your arms. The strong smell will cover your human scent." It is little nuggets like this, in addition to all the other information he provided of course, that made it a joy to be guided by Orphan. 

After a 20-minute walk, carefully navigating the sagebrush and occasional clumps of trees, we spotted the elephant herd. It was remarkable how well they blended into their surroundings, almost disappearing in the sparse vegetation. Suddenly, two elephants peeled off from the group and started heading in our direction.

Orphan quickly identified them as young bulls in musth, a state of heightened aggression accompanied by a large rise in reproductive hormones. Heavy secretions from their temporal glands are a clear sign that an elephant is in musth. Female elephants also secrete from temporal glands when under stress.

"We need to keep our distance," he cautioned. "These bulls are under a lot of stress."

The two bulls continued their approach, their ears flapping and trunks swaying. My heart pounded as the two bulls approached, but Orphan's calm demeanor reassured me. Orphan calmly called out, "We are here!" several times, explaining that this would let the elephants know of our presence and hopefully encourage them to change course. Moments later, the matriarch of the herd appeared. She raised her trunk, sniffing the air in our direction before gently nudging the bulls away from us.

During the tense standoff, I managed to snap a few blurry photos of the two bulls when they were a little too close for comfort. As the matriarch led her herd away, I captured a few more shots, this time with slightly better focus.

We watched the elephants browse peacefully for another 20 minutes, marveling at their size and grace, before making our way back to camp. It was thrilling to witness these majestic creatures in their natural habitat, even if it was a bit nerve-wracking at times!

Bull elephant in musth, too close for comfort; we are on foot

Elephants smelling in our direction before walking away

Lunch

Shortly after returning from our walk, Shine had lunch ready for us. Expecting basic food, we were pleasantly surprised with delicious veg burgers. Shine is quite the cook!

First lunch in the bush: veggie burgers

Afternoon Game Walk

After a short break (late lunch - so no siesta), we set out for our afternoon game walk at 4:00 pm, heading east. Orphan provided detailed information about the vegetation, geography, and animal behavior. He explained how termite mounds shape the delta. Every island we see in the delta often started as a termite mound. Fascinatingly, termite hills tilt west for ventilation, a phenomenon I plan to read more about.

Our first stop was at a dead acacia tree, where we watched zebra, lechwe, and warthogs bask in the warm glow of the setting sun. We also observed two elephant herds, one of which was the same group we had a close encounter with earlier. This time, we were able to identify the herd's composition: 3 young bulls in musth, 2 calves, 2 juveniles, and 4 females, including what appeared to be the matriarch.

Watching elephants from a distance

In the photo above, you can see the sky grey. This is because of the smoke from all the grass being burnt off in the delta. The locals do this to rejuvenate the land and clear the grass before the water from the Angolan highlands arrives in the delta.

Next, we reached the edge of a large waterbody to watch birds, with many storks and herons present. A red lechwe put on a show as the sun set, making the scene even more magical. We then headed back to camp.

Lechwe putting on a show

We were about 50 meters from the camp when an impala shot out of the bushes right in front of us, startling us. Right behind it came three wild dogs in pursuit. Wild dogs chase their prey until it tires before bringing it down. I managed to get a quick, albeit unfocused, shot of a running wild dog. This was our last sighting for the day. 

Painted wild dogs chasing an impala

Find below the map of our walking routes for the day, with sighting marked out. 

Dinner and end of day

Returning to camp, Orphan briefed us on camp discipline. He emphasized the importance of staying within the tent at night, as the darkness brought out the delta's more unpredictable creatures. We were also not to venture beyond the camp perimeter after sundown.

Shine once again worked his culinary magic, preparing another delicious dinner for us. It had been a long, tiring day, so we retired early, falling asleep to the enchanting sounds of the African night: hyena calls, hippo grunts, and the distant trumpet of an elephant.

A video of the camp site, after the tents were erected is below. 

Coming up next

Close encounter with the lions...

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 3, Okavango Delta (15 June, Day 1 of safari)
entry.content:
Story so far:

  • Dublin to Botswana
  • Day 1, Maun (13 June)
  • Day 2, Moremi Game Reserve Day Trip (14 June)

Our 10-Day Mobile Safari Itinerary

Before we dive into the action, let me lay out our 10-day safari itinerary. See the map below for reference.

  • Start: Island Safari Lodge (Point A on the map)
  • Days 1-2: Camping on an island in the Okavango Delta, with walking safaris each day (Point B on the map; zoom in for more details).
  • Days 3-5: Camping in the Moremi Game Reserve near Second Bridge, with two game drives per day (Point C).
  • Day 6: Camping at Magotho Campsite, with evening and night game drives (Point D).
  • Days 7-9: Camping in Savuti, with two game drives per day (Point E).
  • Day 10: Drop-off in Kasane and a relaxing Chobe River cruise (Point G)

10-day mobile safari itinerary map

Maun to Okavango Delta

Today is day 3 in Botswana and the first day of our 10-day mobile safari. It's Saturday, June 15, 2024. We had a bit of a late start, as Chaitra and Niharika woke up feeling under the weather with headaches and sore throats. We suspected it was either dust from the previous day's trip to Moremi or a minor virus. Nevertheless, after a good breakfast and a dose of Lemsip, they decided to trudge ahead. 

As I would later discover on day 4, it was indeed a virus - a new one to us, perhaps. We all suffered two days of sore throats and general misery before things started to improve, but I must say, Chaitra and Niharika never once complained. 

We checked out of Island Safari Lodge at 8:30 AM and met Sedi and Shine. Shine is our chef, and Sedi will drive us to the Morutsa Mokoro Station in the NG/32 Okavango Kopano Mokoro Community. We set off at 9:00 AM. The drive was dusty and bumpy, as expected, and took nearly two hours.

See the map below for the details of our driving route. Due to this being a drought year, the water is only now starting to flow. Water from the Angolan Highlands, specifically from the Cuito and Kavango Rivers, is just reaching the Okavango Delta. As a result, the mokoro station has been moved about 2 km further northwest to where there is water. Consequently, our mokoro trip from the station to the campsite will only be 2 km instead of the usual 4 km.

Maun to mokoro station: driving map

Mokoro station to camping site

Continuing with our journey...

We met with Ofilwe (Orphan from here on - a name that came out of a mistranslation when Ofilwe was in safari field guide school 30 years ago) and his team of polers - two of his uncles and his niece. They are Case, Steve and Mentle (means beautiful). Sedi and Shine loaded all our camping kit from the jeep trailer to the mokoros and handed us off to Orphan. At first, Orphan came across as a little abrasive, but within an hour, our frequencies had matched. He seemed to have a lot of respect for safari-goers who have a genuine interest in Botswana, its history, and its wildlife, which we certainly do.

We all set off on the mokoros from the mokoro station to the campsite. The 2 km distance took us the better part of 90 minutes to cover, mainly because we went slow and stopped many times to listen to Orphan explain something about the landscape, birds, or animals we saw. 

Mokoro (dugout canoe) trip to our campsite. Right to left: Chaitra, Niharika, Orphan, Kiran, Steve

watching wildlife: a black heron and the hippos

Once we arrived at the campsite, Orphan and his team set up the camp, which included a tent for us, tents for Orphan, his team, and Shine, and a dining area. Our tent came with the added luxury of an en suite: open-air shower and a pit latrine. This was our first encounter with this rustic bathroom setup, a stark contrast to the porcelain thrones we're accustomed to. Let's just say it was an experience that required a bit of an adjustment, and one that we'd be getting very familiar with over the next 10 days.

Our tent at the campsite, Okavango delta

This was our first time camping in the wild. All around us were elephant droppings, and there was even a hippo highway not 50 meters from the camp. See the map below for details of the route taken by the mokoro.

Mokoro station to camping site: mokoro trip map

Once our tent was erected, Chaitra and Niharika decided to take a short nap. I sat down at the dining table to write my diary. Shine and Mentle got down to preparing lunch. Steve went off to scout the area around the camping site. 

Camp site (video)


Video of the campsite before erecting the tents.

Exciting encounters on the afternoon of Day 1 of the safari.

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 2, Moremi Game Reserve Day Trip (14 June)
entry.content:
To catch up on the story so far, check out the last two blog posts: Dublin to Maun and Day 1 at Maun.

Early morning start

On the chilly morning of June 14th, we woke up at 4:30 AM, excited and ready for a full day safari to Moremi. By 5:30 AM, we had arrived at the entrance of Island Safari Lodge, where we met our guide, Broken (for more on English translation of Tswana names see Day 1 at Maun), and the four other adventurers joining us for the day. The group included three German students studying in South Africa and a German lady who had impressively been on safaris for the past 28 days, having just arrived from Etosha National Park. Talk about a seasoned pro!

As we prepared to set off, we were greeted by a biting cold morning. For the first time, we realized that the vehicle we would be traveling in was completely open, meaning we would be fully exposed to the windchill during our upcoming two and a half hour drive. Broken handed us parkas, which we gratefully accepted before setting off on our adventure. Thank Gods!

Our journey began with a 60-minute drive to Buffalo Gate, the barrier between the game reserve and the land used for agriculture and cattle grazing. At the gate, both vehicles and people undergo disinfection to prevent the spread of foot and mouth disease from the wild animals to the cattle. Once past the Buffalo Gate, we continued on a bumpy 90-minute ride on a gravel road to reach Moremi South Gate, the official entrance to the game reserve.  While we'd already started spotting wildlife, the real safari was about to begin.

And so, off we went... into the chilly morning. Some of us with spirits high and some of us miserable in the windchill. 

See the map below for the driving route and the areas we covered in the game drive for the day. Zoom in for the details for where we saw what animals. 

Notes on dressing for an early morning Safari

When heading out on a winter safari in Africa, it's essential to dress appropriately for the fluctuating temperatures. Early morning temperatures can plummet to as low as 5 degrees Celsius, though it warms up considerably later in the day. The key is to dress in layers. Our ensemble consisted of vests, safari shirts, safari trousers, woolen socks, jumpers, woolen gloves, tube scarves, and woolen hats. Despite these layers, the cold was biting, and without the parkas provided by our guide, the drive would have been miserable. By 8 AM, it was warm enough to shed the parkas and woolen gloves. By 9 AM, we swapped our woolen hats for safari hats, and by 10 AM, the jumpers were off. However, by 5 PM, the jumpers were back on as the temperature dropped again.

And then, there's the dust.  It's the stuff of legends, the fine white powder that manages to infiltrate every crevice and orifice.  Your clothes, your hair, your nose, your throat – nothing is safe from its relentless pursuit.  A good tube scarf is essential for shielding your face and neck from the sun and the omnipresent dust.  If you have a tendency for your nose to dry out, like mine does due to a deviated septum, it's a good idea to bring something to moisten and irrigate your nose.

With the cold, it's easy to forget the sun, but do so at your own peril.  Sunscreen is an absolute must, even in the winter months.  The combination of cold and dust can also wreak havoc on your skin, so don't skimp on the hand cream and moisturizer.

One final piece of advice: if you have a bad back, a safari might not be the most comfortable vacation choice.  The gravel roads are notoriously bumpy, and the constant jostling in the open vehicle is reminiscent of a camel ride. But for those who can handle a bit of discomfort, the incredible wildlife sightings and breathtaking landscapes are more than worth the occasional ache and rattle.

Note on what to bring

At the end of this series, I will write a separate blog post about what to bring, why, and I will also list what we brought and missed. That post is probably 4 weeks away. 

Mobnet

A high-frequency radio channel known as Mobnet is commonly used by safari guides in Botswana to maintain communication with each other. This radio network is essential for coordinating movements, sharing sightings of wildlife, and ensuring the safety of both guides and tourists in the vast wilderness areas where mobile phone signals may not be reliable.

Mobnet allows guides to quickly relay information about animal locations, road conditions, and potential hazards, thereby enhancing the overall safari experience by making sure everyone is in the right place at the right time to see the best wildlife. It's an integral part of the efficient and safe operation of safaris, particularly in the expansive and sometimes challenging terrains of Botswana’s national parks and game reserves.

It is important to note that you have to be a registered guide to get on the channel. I could not find any further details online about Mobnet.

Moremi South Gate and Beyond

As we passed through Buffalo Gate, giraffes and elephants sporadically appeared, though we didn't stop for any of them. "More to come once inside Moremi South Gate," promised Broken. Our anticipation built as we continued our journey.

First sightings

Upon reaching Moremi South Gate, Broken registered our entrance and paid the park fees while we took the opportunity to enjoy our packed breakfast. This stop was also our last chance to use the toilets, which were impressively clean – a common feature in all public facilities we encountered in Botswana.

Once inside Moremi South, we were greeted by an abundance of wildlife. Zebras, impalas, elephants, giraffes, and antelopes roamed freely, offering us a glimpse of the rich biodiversity of the region.

About an hour into the drive, Broken picked up some exciting chatter on the Mobnet radio – a leopard had been spotted resting nearby. What followed was a thrilling "Schumacher safari," named after the famed race car driver for the speed and agility with which guides maneuver their vehicles to a sighting. Ten minutes of skidding around corners later, we arrived at a clump of acacia brush and found a majestic male leopard. He lay there, unfazed by our presence, for a good twenty minutes, even with a noticeable gash on his right shoulder, possibly from a hunt or a fight.

Our first leopard sighting

With plans to return later, we moved on. More Mobnet chatter soon led us to another clump of acacia where we found two lionesses, a lion, and two cubs. The cubs, shy and quick, disappeared into the bushes before we could photograph them. The lion, however, seemed a bit annoyed by our presence but otherwise remained drowsy, allowing us to observe them for another twenty minutes.

Our first lion sighting

Our next encounter, guided by more Mobnet chatter, was with a pack of resting wild dogs. Known for their incredible hunting success rate of 80%, these predators are among Africa's most fearsome. They chase their prey to exhaustion, often eating it alive – a gruesome sight we were spared as this pack was contentedly resting. With only around 6,000 wild dogs left in Southern Africa, we felt extremely fortunate to witness these rare creatures.

Wild dogs in Moremi

By this point, hunger had set in. Broken found a lovely spot for a picnic lunch where we relished our packed meal of breaded chicken – never had a simple lunch tasted so good.

Lunch time. Kiran distributing Malarone; Niharika with her breaded chicken.

After Lunch

After lunch, we set out to find the lions again, but they had moved on. However, we were in luck with the leopard. We found him very close to where he was in the morning, now sitting with blood on his whiskers. A closer inspection revealed a half-eaten warthog in the grass behind him. Since we had last seen him, he had managed to hunt and was now in the middle of a hearty meal. We watched him for another ten minutes before moving on.

Throughout the afternoon, we continued to see more giraffes, impalas, zebras, and elephants. While we came primarily to see large land mammals, we were pleasantly surprised by the variety of birds. It's impossible to complete a safari here without developing an interest in the avian life.

A lilac breasted roller bird

Area covered during the safari today


More photos

For more photos of the day trip, see the photo album.

Meeting Mark and plans for tomorrow

By about 4 PM, we began our journey back to Island Safari Lodge. On the way we met a convoy of self drivers who told us there was a leopard resting on a dead tree close by. We went looking for the leopard - but no luck. We arrived at the Island Safari Lodge at 6 PM. 

When we got back, Mark from Shipungo Safari & Tours was waiting for us. On a side note, Mark is his middle name. His full name is Oarabile Mark Gaolathwe. Oarabile, translated to English, means "God has answered." It is a Setswana name often given to children who are seen as a blessing or an answer to prayers. Additionally, Shipungo means Bateleur in Tswana.

Tomorrow, we check out after breakfast and will be picked up by our safari guide at 8 AM to start our 10-day mobile safari organized by Mark, who owns and runs Shipungo Safari & Tours. Mark is here to meet us in person, provide an update on the itinerary, and answer any questions we might have. Here’s the summary of our conversation:

2 days in Okavango Delta

For the 2 days in the Okavango Delta, Ofilwe will be our guide, and Phatsimo (who prefers to be called Shine - the English translation of his name) will be our chef. Ofilwe will have a team of polers to transport us and the camping gear from the mokoro station to the campsite and back. The Tswana name Ofilwe translates to "(He/She has been) Given" in English. It is a name given to kids who are seen as a blessing. We will find out tomorrow that Ofilwe has taken Orphan as his English name. A translation mistake from 30 years ago that has stuck.

8 days in Moremi and Savuti

Kem, the guide for the remaining 8 days, will join us on the morning of day 3. Shine (Phatsimo) will remain our chef, and KG, the camp hand, will also join us.

End of day

After showering and attempting to get the dust off us as best as we could, we enjoyed a drink next to the fire pit, followed by dinner, and went to bed early. Looking forward to starting the mobile safari tomorrow. 

Evening by the firepit

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 1, Maun (13 June)
entry.content:
Objectives of the blog

We had done our research, pouring over three Lonely Planet guidebooks (covering Africa in general, Kenya, Tanzania, Botswana and Namibia) and countless online blogs and forums, especially on Reddit and Tripadvisor. But, upon landing in Africa we quickly realized that reading alone doesn't fully prepare you for the adventure that awaits. So, this is our effort to describe the safari from a first-time safari-goers' perspective while also chronicling the interesting things we saw there. If this blog helps a few people in planning their safari, I will consider the time spent on writing this blog well spent. 

Island Safari Lodge and a spontaneous decision

In my last post, I described our flight from Dublin to Maun. Continuing on...

Niharika and a Canadair (Bombardier) Regional Jet 100

Fresh off our flight, we were met at the airport by a driver from the Island Safari Lodge. The lodge, nestled on the banks of the Thamalakane River, is a mere 11 km and 20-minute drive from the airport. 

We had intentionally arrived two days early to avoid any last-minute travel hiccups, and it turned out to be a wise decision. With a spare day on our hands, we inquired at reception about any activities. We lucked out – they had a small group heading to Moremi Game Reserve the following day, and we were invited to join at a discounted rate of BWP 1,700.00 per person. Plus BWP 200.00 per person extra if wanted packed lunch (which we did). It was a spontaneous decision, but we couldn't resist the opportunity to get a taste of the African safari experience before our main adventure began.

One of the first things we learned from the friendly receptionist was that most locals have an "English" name they use with visitors – a thoughtful translation of their Tswana names. This was done to save us from the embarrassment of butchering their beautiful, but sometimes tongue-twisting, Tswana names. We would soon get a taste of this unique custom when we were introduced to our guides for the Moremi Game Reserve day trip: Sixteen and Broken. Sixteen, so named due to a translation quirk (or perhaps a playful sense of humor), would be briefing us on the itinerary. Broken, who was missing the little finger on his right hand, would be our guide in the field. Interesting English names, these! Certainly added a touch of local charm to the experience. 

Shopping in Maun

Before setting off to explore, we asked about the best places to stock up on essentials in Maun. Our receptionist, always ready to help, kindly offered to call a trusted taxi for us. After a quick lunch, we were on our way to Maun town. Our taxi driver was aptly named "Trust" (his given name in Tswana is Tshepang). The word "tshepa" in Tswana translates to "trust" in English.

A 20-minute drive brought us back to Maun town, where we needed to buy some water, some scotch, and a couple of Botswana SIM cards. Our first stop was Choppies, one of the two main supermarkets in Maun (the other being Spar). Choppies also has two ATMs outside and a state-run money exchange bureau.

The bureau staff were incredibly helpful when I needed to break down my USD 50 bills into smaller denominations. They suggested I convert some money into Botswana Pula (BWP), which would allow them to give me smaller USD bills for the rest. It was a simple solution, and I left with a mix of BWP and USD in smaller bills, perfect for tipping (which is generally preferred in either BWP or USD). We even had a friendly chat with the ladies at the bureau, who were eager to know if we were enjoying Botswana so far. "Ask me again in 12 days!" I quipped, hoping the rest of our trip would live up to the initial positive impression. I have a feeling after 12 days, my answer will be "absolutely!".

Work at money exchange bureau done, I decided to try my luck at an ATM. As expected, withdrawing BWP directly with my VISA debit card yielded the most favorable exchange rate, factoring in both the spread and fees.

With cash in hand, we stocked up on water and fruit at Choppies. We had been informed that we'd only receive one liter of water per person during the day safari, so we grabbed extra bottles, knowing that tap water in Maun wasn't safe to drink.

Next, we crossed the road to Liquorama, where we splurged on a bottle of Johnnie Walker Black Label for BWP 500 – a treat for our upcoming sundowners in the bush.

Our final mission was to acquire SIM cards. We popped into a nearby shop, but the kind lady there, upon learning our safari itinerary (Maun -> Okavango -> Moremi -> Khwai -> Savuti -> Kasane), advised us that a BTC (Botswana Telecoms) SIM card would be a better choice for our travels. She even pointed us to a different shop that sold them. At this point, I was really beginning to appreciate the helpfulness and integrity of the people here.

We proceeded to buy two BTC SIM cards from a roadside shop for BWP 10 each. Although there was a BTC outlet in Choppies, they informed us that they couldn't activate a prepaid BTC SIM card and directed us to the BTC office. So, we got back in the taxi and headed to the BTC office. On the way, we spotted a Nando's. This South African fast-food chain has made its way to even the smaller towns of Botswana, where a meal there is considered quite the fancy affair.

There was a long queue at the BTC office. After about 45 minutes, the two SIM cards were activated. We then purchased a 5 GB data package (14-day validity) for both SIMs at BWP 99.00 each. Right - we are all set now: water bottles, scotch, and BTC SIM cards with data and voice.

Tshepang (or Trust), shared some local wisdom with us: people here love their alcohol and driving late in the evening on payday is not a great idea. Duly noted!

Winding up for the day

We arrived back at the Island Safari Lodge around 6:30 pm and settled up with Trust, paying him BWP 400 – BWP 300 for the taxi and BWP 100 as a tip for his patience and friendly service. It seemed like a fair deal for both of us.

Back at the lodge, we took in the sight of the dry Thamalakane Riverbed, a stark reminder of the drought. During wetter years, the river teems with hippos and crocodiles, which can be observed from a viewing deck right next to the lodge restaurant. But tonight, it was just us, the quiet hum of the lodge, and the anticipation of our first game drive. After a quick shower and dinner, we packed our bags for the next day and turned in early. Our Moremi adventure awaited us, and we were eager to see what the African bush had in store.

Next up

Our first day in an African game reserve!

entry.title: Botswana 2024: Day 0, Dublin to Botswana (12 June)
entry.content:
Dublin to Jo'burg

Our safari is set to kick off in Maun and wrap up in Kasane, but first, we must navigate a series of flights that could politely be described as "interesting." Our journey began in Dublin, with a smooth Etihad flight to Abu Dhabi (AUH). The eight-hour layover in AUH was a breeze, thanks to the airport's usual efficiency and a delicious dinner at Todd English. 

As we passed through AUH, I was reminded that every airport has its own quirks when it comes to security. In AUH, laptops are the only items you need to remove from your bag. Liquids can be left in the bag as long as they're in containers of 100ml or less. So far, so good.

Things took a turn for the, well, let's just say "interesting," when we arrived at Johannesburg's O.R. Tambo Airport (JNB). While AUH had spoiled us with endless dining options, JNB made finding a decent cup of coffee feel like an epic hunt. The airport itself is massive, with Terminal A for international flights and Terminal B for domestic. We arrived in Terminal A, collected our bags, and then had to trek over to Terminal B to check in for our CemAir flight to Maun (apparently, even international CemAir flights check in at the domestic terminal... nope, not confusing at all). Once that was sorted, we marched back to Terminal A for boarding. Simple.

If you're flying through JNB, do yourself a favor and get to passport control and security early. The queues can be long and chaotic, with a seemingly inefficient system that had only three (out of 8-9) passport check booths manned during peak hours. We witnessed a few desperate passengers jumping the queue because their flights were about to close, which, after the calm efficiency of DUB and AUH, was a bit of a shock. But hey, we were too exhausted to care at that point.

One final tip for those traveling from South Africa to Botswana: you can't buy spirits in duty-free and bring them on the flight. You're limited to South African wines. So if you were planning on stocking up on gin (or in my case, scotch) for your safari sundowners, you'll need to buy all that in Botswana.

With that rich experience behind us, we finally made it to our boarding gate in Terminal A. Next stop: Botswana!

DUB -> AUH -> JNB (map created using https://www.rome2rio.com/)

Who we are

Before I get ahead of myself, a quick intro. 

The Hegdes and a Canadair (Bombardier) Regional Jet 100 (the 50 seater JNB-MUB flight)

Our safari adventure is a family affair, with the three of us - each with our own quirks and passions - ready for our first safari. There's me, the self-proclaimed romantic (or "armchair romantic," if you believe my wife). My wife, the ever-enthusiastic traveller, would never turn down the chance to visit a new and exciting destination. And then there's our daughter, the budding foodie and photographer, who's just as eager to sample new cuisine as she is to capture the perfect shot of our adventures. 

Jo'burg to Maun

Boarding the CemAir flight to Maun, we were delighted to find it barely 30% full. All three of us scored window seats and marvelled at the terrain below during the 90-minute flight. Despite CemAir's indifferent online reviews, our experience was quite the opposite. The flight was on time, comfortable, and came with a satisfying lunch. We were served a hearty sandwich, an energy bar, a bag of chutney-flavored crisps that reminded us of India, a beer, and a bottle of water.

Upon arrival in Maun, baggage collection and immigration were a breeze. Customs did stop us briefly to inquire about any seeds or food items, but our stash of energy bars, roasted cashews, almonds, and walnuts passed inspection without a hitch. The customs officer even shared a chuckle with us, remarking that every traveler seems to favor cashews and almonds.

JNB -> MUB (map created using https://www.rome2rio.com/)

Aerial views: JNB to MUB flight

Gazing out the window of our CemAir flight, we were treated to a stunning view of the landscape below. The terrain shifted from the dense forests of northwest South Africa to sparser desert vegetation as we entered Botswana and continued further northwest. One fascinating sight was the cultivated parcels of land northwest of Johannesburg, which were circular instead of the usual quadrilateral shapes. A quick Google search revealed that this is due to the increasing use of center pivot irrigation. If you're curious, you can read more about pivot irrigation here or check out a paper from 2004 discussing its effectiveness in South Africa.

Crop circles? Nope, just center pivot irrigation! Image from https://google.com/maps

The sheer number of rivers snaking through the landscape below was incredible. I haven't seen so many rivers flying across Europe or India. It was a powerful reminder of the life-giving force of water in this arid landscape. The roads below us seemed to stretch endlessly in straight lines, underscoring the flatness of the Botswana terrain. We also noticed several bush fires, their origins unclear – a stark reminder of the challenges posed by drought in this region.

In the morning, the rivers appeared white, shrouded in mist, while later in the day, they seemed to take on a greenish hue, reflecting the surrounding vegetation. Many rivers had wide, sandy banks with little water, a clear sign of the ongoing drought. 

From the air, it was also evident that most homes in Botswana have metal roofs, a practical and enduring choice. These practical roofs, gleaming in the sunlight, seemed to be a ubiquitous feature of the Botswana landscape.

Next post: our first day in Maun!

entry.title: Second post
entry.content:
Remember that time back in 2022 when I swore I'd finally start writing about my travels? Yeah, me neither.  One lonely post was all I managed before life (and a few more countries) got in the way. Greece, Italy (for the third time), Spain, Portugal - they're all still rattling around in my head, waiting to be put into words.

This time around, I’m unexpectedly unemployed, and I’m planning to take a career break to enjoy the summer of 2024 with my family and travel a bit. We just got back from Botswana - our first safari - and I realize if I don’t write a blog about our travels in Botswana, I never will. 

I'll be sharing all the highlights (and maybe a few lowlights) over the next few posts, and then I'll dish out all the nitty-gritty details on how we planned it all.

Stay tuned for the next installment!
